FKoyQFVYOHd-7n7FfqEicQ.review_text: good weeknight place to go and hang out... ...one thing i did not like was people were smoking in the outside seating area and since the cafe is so small smoke was right on my face...i might as well have smoked that day...it's better than 2nd hand smoking....

KEcp56uOQq3XYkJicuLjuA.review_text: Okay, I've now bumped this review up by 2 stars since I first wrote about it.  I was initially pretty irked by slow-ass service and apathetic staff and I still wouldn't recommend it as a place to go when you are antsy and out-and-about.  Life moves pretty slow here so don't come here for instant food/drink gratification.  Still, everything else about this place is top-notch.  It's hard to beat access to beer, wine, coffee, nightly live music, and free wi-fi all in one place.  In the daytime, sit outside and read/write/whatever with a cigarette and some wine and you'll be sure to feel like one of those Americans slumming it out in Europe.    And in the evening, it's a whole different story.  You can walk by and see live music just about every night and on some occasions I remembered they had Tango lessons.  Just a cool place all around.  Perhaps it's a good thing that service is mediocre otherwise this place would get more crowded than it already is.

dKNOYYr38Zzq2ZmkCAZuzw.review_text: Not a bad place to get some coffee and a bite to eat. Expect to get doobie smoke blown all over you indiscriminately though.

QBXAIu1Vm-nKXUwBqZ5H7Q.review_text: You say you want a Revolution...well, ya know...don't go on a Friday night when you're shoulder pad to shoulder pad and knee dip in tight jean cuffs and carrying around a duffel bag full of dance shoes, fishnets and lingerie.   Don't especially walk with said bag through the crowded room and pause in motion to be polite to let another ignorant soul walk by you and knock into the bag--very impolite!  Like um, any Friday night, you slowly turn around and wince to see a precariously perched glass of Sangria all aglow next to a shiny new macbook. Again, who studies in a crowded club with a table full of booze and thousands of dollars worth of elite computer equipment next to it?  The bartender was nice enough to give us a deal on the drinks spilled and I slugged mine pretty fast and got the hell out of there. I knew there would be trouble going in there as I watched the crowds from across the street, but I caved in to the bf.  I'd go back, but only during the day time for a leisurely time, maybe for a snack, maybe some wine, but definitely not to battle the Friday night Mission crowds. I'm getting too old for that nonsense. Or maybe I was just too sober.  It's better to buy a glass of wine for someone instead of a laptop though on a Friday night. That much, I can say.

FysDiqCS1fxxwC9PLHNqNg.review_text: For years I've been coming here. Often on Tuesday evenings. I sometimes brought a friend or two, other times I came alone. Always a woman in a black hat wearing black dress and dark glasses, I sometimes grabbed a vegetable panini, other times I stuck with a glass of red. Whenever I stepped into the place, it made me feel like I was at a local bar found in the Latin Quarter, 5th arrondissement, my favorite district in Paris, until I was in Stockholm last year, where I went inside of Jazzpuben Stampen. The EC reminded me a smaller version of Stampen (if you can imagine an even smaller venue than Stampen). Stampen is located in the old town, where among the jazz luminaries posters on the wall, was an odd duckling of Woody Allen photo, who also played there. No Woody Allen on site at the RC. A famous San Francisco Jazz musician aka Harvard 89 alumni Anton Schwartz, whom I had seen performing with the Boston Pops in May during Harvard 89's 25th Harvard reunion, had indeed played there, once, or twice, so I was told, by someone who used to date him in college.   I always tell people to meet me there because it felt, despite its San Franciscaness, very out of place. For a while, the wine only costed $5, now $7.5, still affordable, though sandwiches remained at $5 a pop. It's way classier than the Make Out Room, across the street.   I can tell you which nights to show up to chill: Mondays, Tuesdays and Sundays. Don't go on Friday because some of the more popular bands are playing and you'd have no seats in a warm summer night. Though a friend of mine's band was really good and I once organized a gathering there to watch his band performing, but I quickly realized that when they played, everyone danced, on the sidewalk and street. It was a lovely summer evening. You would not need a seat, no one sat down that night.  On those quieter days I listened to classical music and read my book, and on occasion I would chat with friends. It's not exactly a pick up joint, and it's not a date place. For that, I'm grateful.

hP8by2q4mgfQEvvhfChcbQ.review_text: I love this place...its a perfect treat on a crisp evening or  sunny afternoon. Its refreshing to be in the company of good music and company where people seem to be having real conversations with good friends. I love the set up with the big open front leading to good people watching of people both passing by and within the bar. Any day I spend time here gives me that warm tingly "I had a great day in San Francisco" feeling.   I do wish they served desert...

WddCwwoYlVDZKGzfqRSWWg.review_text: you know, that place. in the mission, on a corner, tiny, always packed, tables outside, red interior walls, live music? if you could still smoke in bars there would be clouds billowing out, along with notes of trumpet or snare drum or piano. yeah, you know the place.    but did you know they serve possibly the creamiest, chunkiest tomato soup ever? a cup costs something silly, like $2.25, and it comes with bread. my friend jen and i snagged a table early on a saturday night, but jen's doing some sort of "cleanse" that prohibits alcohol, and i'm just trying to get less fat, so we kept buying little club sodas and things to assuage our guilt for occupying such a primo spot. but there's only so much mint tea a girl can drink. that's when i discovered the tomato soup. mmmm. highly recommend it.   awesome spot.

9ulOnur9iBus_O5Pz8yiYA.review_text: This is a great place for a beer and a laptop! I came here on one of the hot days in August (yes, there is such a thing in summer in SF)  decent music, good wifi connectivity... and a cafe that serves beer (chimay) and offers free WiFi (yes, I'm a geek:)) - what more can u ask?  the place is very lively even @ 11.30pm @ nite... Its great... and the smell of weed keeps u going too :) second hand weed, i dont mind :)

JIRyx-vf6k4B1wqRBTWi9w.review_text: I really like this place.  Feels very European.  Live music, fairly priced drinks, hefe on tap, eclectic crowd, open air ambiance.  Cool.  I do have to say though, there get some serious freaks there.  The three of us were sitting next to some weird black-glasses wearing, identical robots that were shushing us for talking while they scribbled in their notebooks - they were clearly highly creative types.  Ha.  Go to a library!

YbHG7tkX81Y5cbsvhYf6eA.review_text: Pros: The music is almost always amazing.  If you are in the mood for people watching. this is a super good place for it. It's a real, old-school, hang out and talk about philosophy and politics kinda place. The coffee is fine, and if I drank beer I'm sure I would be stoked about the chimay.  thing to know: there is often smoke that drifts inside. Don't go here if that will freak you out. However, if you are like me ( a former smoker who spent her teenage years in very smokey seattle cafes), it won't bother you much as it doesn't get TOO smokey. Also, don't go here to study unless you are really good at concentrating. This is more of a hanging out place.    cons: The service has always totally sucked. I am a good customer. I'm polite. I tip. I'm never in a hurry. Still, it has always been super slow even when there is nothing going on.....like they literally ignore me as I wait to order. Also, at least twice I have been there when two employees were there who apparently couldn't agree on the volume of the music and kept turning it up and down.

JhSwZhHTMUfNcRo47peJJQ.review_text: I love this place... good memories =)  I know cafes are overly abundant in s.f. however of all this one was my favorite.  I've met some cool ppl just hanging out there myself.  They serve some food items ( I had yogurt with granola ) and of course their deal of coffees, teas...and also wine.  It's very chill and relaxed, seems like a nice friendly neighborhood hangout place... There are table inside, and also some small tables out front. I've seen young adults, adults, and teens there. Sometimes they have live performances and I really enjoyed the Sunday live classical music performance =) It goes until around midnight...well though it's been months since I was there I suppose you can check the latest happenings and schedule on their Myspace.  It seems like a more "down to earth" feeling in there and the setting is not modern nor pristine, yet I enjoy it.  Oh yes, there is a hostile right by there so you have a chance of meeting or making conversation with foreigners or travelers...or vagabonds too, lol!

mROok9JZx19AwvOJlI8FHQ.review_text: Just got back from a sunny afternoon in the Mission (as opposed to back here in the cold and foggy Richmond). Most of it was spent hanging out at Revolution Cafe - reading, drinking tea, and writing letters to friends.  I end up coming here a lot when I have time off during the day and I always have a great time. Lots of active people watching, listening in on conversation in Spanish, enjoying artists sketching in their pads, and taking in the sun on a lightly breezy afternoon.  They've got a solid selection of beers and the sandwhiches have been tasty the few times I've ordered them.   If you're lucky enough to find a seat at night, you can listen in on some awesome jazz/latin music and sometimes people are inspired enough to dance!  The front patio puts this place over the top on the ratings scale. There aren't too many cafes like that in the Mission and if you consider everything else I described, there's no choice but to give it 5 stars!

g5d9HCy8DL4H6U_48S5z1w.review_text: I discovered this true pleasure last night with a few friends.  The place is a complete hole-in-the-wall (we wondered if there were even enough chairs for the 5 of us), but somehow we were situated.    The art-work on the wall is spectacular -- and, for the record, there is political paraphernalia, including a campaign poster from Tom Ammiano's historic mayoral campaign in 1999 (which was my first involvement in local SF politics.)  And Shaun the waitress is hysterical!!  Don't be intimidated by her wise-cracking comments.  She will insult you and berate you, but just laugh and go with the flow.  And if you talk back to her with a witty clever comment, she will love you!

o0oxyu1qnQrutZo1GCGwMw.review_text: Revolution Cafe is one of those bar's that is still trying to hold on to the 60's and that mentality. Buuut it's a pretty cool place to hang-out and people watch and they have some real decent beers on tap. My only issue with the place is the spotty service you will get. the bartenders are usually busy waxing philosophy with some of the regulars so you will have to wait while they argue Nietzsche or whatever book they just read. Other than that the bar is a fun hang-out while you wait for a reservation in the Mission. I do want to come back here and try some of their food so i can comment on that. So to be continued when i do.

FdpFViIWemuIJZeAKpvL5A.review_text: so so relaxing - great atomosphere and great times

YEKy3CEFI23R49tpqlMvbg.review_text: On a nice sunny day, this place is fantastic. They have some nice sidewalk seating and it's great to sit out there with a drink and watch the world go by. At night, there have been times when I've just hung out on the street to watch the bands playing over there. The one downfall is that because it's a small place, seating is pretty limited.

l7MIIt0YoMVWAKa_QTCYkg.review_text: Welcome to SF, to your new neighborhood.  You live above a seriously kick ass cafe, which makes you feel better about leaving Brooklyn.  I have just spent six hours here, and am in fact writing the review from RC.  Its cool, vibey and has great music.   An unusual mix of white boys, construction men, crackheads and me with my dog.

wxI9QYo-wOpU-S97m0Djlw.review_text: All I got there was the free iced coffee from the check in since they don't accept credit cards, but damn was that some good iced coffee.  And they didn't mind my friend and I not buying a single thing and still sitting at the cafe and do a design brainstorming session.  They also had great live music, something we're told happens there daily. Its a sweet place, you should go.

XHuNSjrPA3Vyi7n4iVhZaQ.review_text: Coffee is not that great, but you can't beat sitting outside and pretending like you're in Amsterdam. Except without the choco-mel. Beware the guy with the cowboy hat. Don't get stuck talking to him.

khFA0eLpu7H08JOWtiVF8w.review_text: So I had been here once or twice before for a coffee or something similar, and thought - whoa, grungy, oh, every man here is wearing skinny jeans, oh, this is where the hipsters hang out, what am I doing here again?  However, last night I randomly ended up here again. There was a string quartet and then at some point also a piano player or two playing surprisingly good classical music. Shockingly we found a seat, it wasn't too cold thanks to the heat lamps and when i closed my eyes and everyone stopped talking and just listened to the music...it was a tiny, tiny bit of heaven in the midst of everything else. I wasn't in the Mission district of San Francisco, the people next to me were of no consequence.   I probably gained back a few years of life just by listening to the surprisingly beautiful music for those few minutes there. And for that, The Revolution Cafe, you get 4 stars.

SiHFDtIWG-yJwFLSs7WdhQ.review_text: This place is awesome. $2.00 coffee and wifi access ftw! Perfect place for getting coffee and watching the Mission scene go on around you. And did I mention wifi? I tried two other coffee shops around here and the stingy bastards didn't offer it! Not naming names - cough ritual coffee roasters cough

vgwdQ0fpDZdoTidJuwYq7w.review_text: Ok, I have been to this cafe once before, a friend & I had some wine while watching life cruise by one afternoon a few years back. Nothing particularly interesting grabbed me about it, so haven't been back. However, last night we were walking home and heard the tropical island sound of a siren and a ukulele. We HAD to check it out, and refresh ourselves with another cocktail. Inside were 3 beautiful girls...Paper Dolls, check them out! Singing songs from the 80s to the present along with some originals. At one point one of the songstresses removed her skirt baring cute black short shorts and a rather lovely rear end. The place was packed with sundry folks, not just hipsters, as many reviews mention. I'm not sure I'll be back, but if they have more fascinating acts like that, I sure will try!

LJran3NNjBVimk0raMUskA.review_text: Wouldn't exactly call this a wine bar.  It's more like a grungy cafe that happens to serve wine, wafting of marijuana, poor service by the bartender too busy flirting to attend to the customers standing directly in front of him.

olPfZ8iqJF2e7lgWEicRPQ.review_text: Went there after dinner a Thursday, very too hipster for you. Place was packed. Live jazz stylings was hot  Pretty cool joint, bonus: Racer 5 beer ($4)

NE5eKK89zygL950_Tz-Qgg.review_text: This is a really cool coffee place. Well, they have other types of drinks too but I don't drink so for me, it's all about the mocha. And they make a great mocha. However, they didn't have nonfat milk. I had to drink my mocha with *gasp* low fat milk! I'm wondering if that's why it tasted so good. . .

7KVMsmPjgmJho4_B5aSStQ.review_text: I'm writing my first yelp review from the Revolution Cafe itself.  Free wireless automatically detected, although my laptop still thinks it's "validating identity".  ~8 beers on tap ranging from $4-$6.  I'm currently working on a Sierra Nevada Torpedo (yum, I might have to hit up BeerAdvocate after this).  Very laidback indoor/outdoor-hybrid setting with artsy, price-tagged wall-hangings.  A young and well-dressed crowd is packed in here and is impressively being handled by a sole (cute) bartendress.  The jazzy, worldly playlist nicely complements the dim yet upbeat atmosphere.  Great place to come before or after dinner or any time you're in the area, really.

9BuqtcJ4DMUr7bid_j-nsQ.review_text: Oh dear god this place is great.  Right out of Oberkampf or maybe the Marais.  They have Leffe on tap and bless its heart, the cigarette smoke drifts wonderful in from the streetside seating, which by the way, is exactly how a place like this should smell.

ra-0kkkBQ03BmfefMeKIug.review_text: Such a fun place to chill relax, chit chat, people watch, and listen to random music ranging fom acoustic to a full on band. Yummy ginger tea (will clear your sinuses in 30 sec flat), and ditto for the hot chocolate served not in a mug ,but a BOWL. Oh yea and for you drinkers there's plenty to choose from.

WRiN50ILbu1klAm3Km8qHw.review_text: I like it ! I just like it. This is open until midnight. It has wi-fi. Relaxing atmosphere with wood floor. People are friendly with sense of freedom. The price is reasonable ( small ice coffee is $1.50!).  Hand-made sense. Music is nice. They have a piano.

T4DlbCs9Ghq1n7L7E57XGw.review_text: A cozy, casual, musical cafe. Cheap good beers with live 50s music. The atmosphere is that of the 50s. The balcony is warm for the smokers and .. check out the walls and the bathroom .....

qM1dshJYE15acv9u-R1ULg.review_text: I can spend hours upon hours at Revolution. Daylight, live music, food, coffee, beer, diverse crowd and the scent of "revolution" wafting in from the sidewalk. There are few places that I would rather spend my time at than Revolution. I want to be there right now. My only complaint is that the tables are wobbly (or is it the floor?) who the fuck cares.

IWal1ziP1AlfcgDJj5CKFw.review_text: Pretty good spot.  Live music some times.  An older biddy shushed us when we were talking at our table, catching up, because she was listening to the music.  As it isnt a concert hall and the vibe is chill we gave her a mellow out look and kept on enjoying ourselves.  If she wants uptight, don't hang in the Mission.  Nice selection of beer.  Prices are OK.    They even have seats outside.  I have yet to stop by Rev cafe without smelling its signature scent...

APJRyxqnuD1ZraYXOmnG1w.review_text: This place is a mixed bag. I love the atmosphere and food, and the place brings in a mix of people of all ages, which beats the usual wifi warriors or trust-fund hipsters.  In fact, I'd give it four stars, except for one thing: about half the time, the live music starts up mid-afternoon. This isn't the scheduled music or an evening jam session, mind you, but rather someone who decides that 1 in the afternoon is high time for a building-shaking hoedown. I don't really expect to need earplugs in the middle of the day with my coffee.

YPkXV7QgbUR7S7tnfAtI_Q.review_text: I want to like this place more.  It's got the ambience that I love in cafes, but it seems fake.  And the food's overpriced for what you get.  And the clientele is too damn hip for its own good.  I ordered a champagne concoction cuz I'm smoov like that.  I certainly got a concoction...but very little champagne.  Phase 1:  Champagne Concoction Phase 2:  ??????????????????? Phase 3:  Profits! (for them)

HdW_VZSVFiZTt7VcGIu52w.review_text: papa toby's is a nice alternative to ritual. the coffee isn't nearly as good as ritual, but it's serviceable and as others have noted, there's something to be said about sitting outside on a nice sunny day and watching people go by. this is especially true on 22nd street between bartlett and mission, where the action is always interesting and never boring.  papa toby's also serves beer. so if your party can't decide between coffee and beer, jaunt over to papa toby's and have both.

qD51vvp5Zf5DgPEGy7yfDQ.review_text: Papa Toby's is in a nondescript location on 22nd St.  I had to backtrack because I hadn't realized I passed by it the first time.    There's a small menu of food, but I especially like the extensive drink menu for coffee and alcohol lovers, alike (their largest menu board is dedicated to cocktails).  As others have mentioned, there's a small covered outdoor seating area with heating, along with a decent amount of seating inside.

56cuwY7zLNnoosrOCpFm4g.review_text: If what they are going for here is a too cool to care policy towards the public they've certainly succeeded.  The eclectic atmosphere here can't be beaten, but in order to put up with the noise and bad service I'd want a killer cup of coffee and/or tea - neither of which I got.    It's worth going to this place for the experience rather than the actual thing they sell or provide.    In that way it's a bit like Chuk E. Cheese.  The food is crap but you get to play skeeball and have your photo taken with a budding novelist dressed as a mouse.    Totally worth it.

j45PuQ1uZeljOh4vCmwi3w.review_text: Great freaking sandwiches, but it's just not worth dealing with the really rude staff and long wait. Uber Weak.  Food gets two stars. Wifi and Outdoor area would get 1 star each if it weren't for my inability to enjoy them without wanting to strangle everyone working there.   Love the name. Hate the hipster staff.

jXu7LgleTN3VGXKpz6TxqA.review_text: A great place to start a revolution.

TXTg2Q1mnf_kbewJs2XhPA.review_text: I was unimpressed by this place.  It was PACKED, the tables were tiny, the beer was slightly warm, the server was rude, the service was slow, and the cashier didn't wash her hands when she was moving from task to task.  The bathroom was also disgusting and smelled like old urine.  I won't be back, unless it's just for a drink and to listen to live music.  And even then, maybe not.

UdBgCRXFx6YIZpQFg7hLkw.review_text: One of the many facts of life - laundry sucks.  Everyone hates doing laundry.  However, I find myself lugging my dirty underwear all the way down to 22nd street, just so I can sit at Revolution in a cloud of marijuana smoke while I hope no one steals my clothes.  It makes doing laundry just a little bit better.  Revolution is... basically what you'd expect from a cafe called Revolution: Bob Marley and red stars and angsty hipsters.  I give them props for innovative espresso though, especially their ginger lattes.  What a good idea!  I can't believe I'd never had a ginger latte before. Also highly recommended is the coconut chai latte - it's a little bit funky though, so you have to be prepared for that.  The coffee is nothing to write Yelp about, but it suffices while you're sitting and reading The Motorcycle Diaries.

7iMfopizGqC7_DvECJFtQQ.review_text:
Sidewalk seating with overhead heating for moments of less than perfect weather.  Generally good music and decent daily happy hour specials on a small but choice beer selection.  The coffee isn't fancy but it is potent.  This place rocks.  I play rummy here.
  I don't know what Lisa's problem is, but "revolution" does not mean "equal rights" (reference the Russian Revolution, Iran's Islamic Revolution, China's Cultural Revolution....).  And it's just a cafe.
  I live in this neighborhood and go here alot.  If you don't feel "hip" enough, get over your insecurity.  I don't act too cool 'cause I'm not that weak.  (-lucious jackson)

oMI7eaE2DYfNKpk1CU7spA.review_text: This is a gem, it's a cafe/ bar ish place...one large room, half of which happens to be outside with heat lamps. They have an actual bar for seating as well...which is wonderful. Live music is often playing in the middle of the room, in a way that accents rather than commands, and  the neighborhood is busy, but cozy and comforting at the same time.  It's the sort of thing you might find in a movie... or write about...something you might find yourself hoping for on a sunny day...  I think I may have discovered a new favorite.

0Pd-LScDP0zLf4ShnV8L0Q.review_text: While the live music was good, I sat at a table right next to the band and 1) couldn't hear what any of my friends were saying and 2) eardrums were hurting after a little while.  Drinks = awful. We ordered a couple drinks off of the "cocktails menu" and gosh so disgusting. I could barely swallow the "sangria mojito". I have no idea what kind of cheap sangria mix was used it. There was no fruit or anything fresh appearing like a normal sangria. I think this was probably the only time in my life I've sent a drink back and got a glass of wine instead. Well that's just equally horrendous. Trader Joe's 2 buck chuck is way better... Should have just gone with a beer.  Won't be visiting again at night.

NDdAkv3Ygc30PcPw7zg5kQ.review_text: Hipsters meet beatnicks meet today's SF twenty and thirty somethings, pour together and mix with live music almost every day of the week,and you have Revolution Cafe.  Sangria is yum and I recommend it by the pitcher with a good friend. Didn't have any food, didn't even realize they had food,because here it's about the people watching in the open air and the saaangriaaa!!

LdyVNZyPl6vR0THDPw5zIQ.review_text: Really great vibe to this place.  I'm not that big of an asshole to say the place has a bohemian feel, but it's definitely dark inside and I had a hard time seeing where I was going without walking onto the performing bands' set. Seems like they have a lot of great live and local performers which is even better.   As always, had a great conversation about activism, and people, and experience- a perfect reminder as to why I moved to this city. The experience.

5lvfVuWaJPHx93fDQj-teA.review_text: Well it's already been said a zillion times. Coffee, beer, food and great music and ambience. Seems like a good place to hang out anytime.

mWovMFEZgWE40UVchWHlWA.review_text: This is the second time here....and the experience was great. I don't go there to eat or drink, just drink in the vibe of classical music in a Bohemian setting! Why is it I like it so much..... You'll just have to check it out. Oh, don't forget to put a few dollars in the kitty for the musicians....go to Esperpento's across the street, the MakeOut Room for drinks, or Garcon on the corner! Lord, I love this City!

YCQvJY812RXJ_L1zYFJ5rA.review_text: My friend took me to Revolution Cafe last night, and I think I am in love!!! What a great place! Why do I like it so much? Because they serve good food, have a nice selection of beer, wine and caffeinated drinks, an outdoor seating area on the sidewalk like the cafes in Europe, and to top it off they have really great live music! This place gets packed because it is so awesome... I went on a Thursday and there were lines to both the door and restroom, but I am telling you, it is because Revolution Cafe is a great place to hang out, listen to good music and enjoy a glass (or two or three or four) with friends- it is completely worth waiting in line for. I'm not sure if it's always so crowded, but I actually didn't mind it at all. I think there is a high possibility that I will become a regular.

m-_pnRtoqOxw-zOtDADckQ.review_text: Maybe I'm just not hipster, start a revolution enough, but this place isn't that great.  Not that comfortable of seats, not that great of drinks, not that clean, and never, ever that I've been there a place to sit.  The live string quartet there a few weeks ago was nice, but doesn't make up for the general scene. I'm just not feeling it or as those into it would say, I'm not deep enough to be in love with it.

BcIROC2HnwSFwYxYbZDSuA.review_text: Bomb hot chocolate and latte.  Stopped in for a caffeine fix after late dinner.  Chill place with live music.

QCtO1WiRbxw09lhjMHh4yg.review_text: I've been getting work done here for years. I think of this café as the home of a younger Bohemia. Mission kids hang out here all day, drinking beer or coffee, smoking cigarettes or whatever, making art and conversation, and writing. This is a crazy corner, where you can befriend the folks hanging out or end up feeling like a rube. Do as you like. Nobody cares. The menu's eclectic, and the wifi is free. Electrical outlets and indoor/outdoor seating make it a great place to write.

YmrN1KtTtv1Vqfx8UuhQnQ.review_text: I'd give it five stars if it had a really excellent selection, or great prices, or even just prompt service. Okay, okay... sometimes the service is great. That was unfair. But... there have been times I really wondered if anyone would notice me walking behind the bar and pouring my own, as they clearly weren't noticing me (or the four people behind me) standing at the counter. Pet peeve.  Despite that, this is my favorite place to grab a beer and a book. I'm probably ruining my eyes and my liver, drinking and reading in the low lighting. Luckily, I am often saved from myself by people who want to know what I'm reading. This, by the way, only happens in the booths, where strangers have to sit together. Thus begins an evening of meeting new people.  That's why I go, and why I give it four stars.  **update: they changed the seating all up, and made it a lot harder to get through to the counter. It also makes it harder for folk to talk. I take back one star. Sorry.

_brCA8Zrh5qIsh8hEmY54A.review_text: I used to like this place a lot for its atmosphere and the good music that they have. But now, it's often just full of lost people. I like Bohemia and Art but why is it always supposed to be linked to the smell of pot? I don't find the smooth laid back touch that I used to. Now it's become more about getting stoned in the little outside scene where you can't sit at all unless you want to get stoned as well. I'd rather smoke when I decide to. Plus the music doesn't need to be that loud to be appreciated.  I still like the little tables, the fact that they serve hot drinks, and their good music when it's not too loud. I just try to go when it's not crowded and smelly.

Rg4zgdqQcZMj1PRJ49Hybw.review_text: At night, and on sunny weekends, this is the finest place to get a beer in the area. I love the energy, the live music, and the open storefront spilling out onto the street.  Weekdays, the place is more empty, a great place to sit with your Dostoevsky, or laptop. The music is not too obtrusive to be able to work.   Sad to say, I can offer a mere 3 stars.  The place is often understaffed; the coffee at best uneven and burnt. The daytime barista either doesn't know or doesn't give a damn how to use the expresso machine. It can take a revolution to extract a morsel from the kitchen.  Some may be put off by the smoke that sometimes wafts in from the front booths.  Que Tal up on Guerrero (spacious and workable), Ritual (for the coffee and fever) or Atlas(all round) rank higher up in my book - that is, in terms of wifi cafes where you can sit and study with a solid mug of Joe.

_7DXxuBLD_1cAq92cgK_mg.review_text: Interesting place....now I know where all the "off the griders"(I think I just made this word up!)  hang Thursday nights are the best here, open mic followed by a live band. The beer selection is good, though sometimes the beers can be flat. I have  not tried any food, but their americanos are pretty good.

onMQq3O_OWqv6JqajDOu3g.review_text: five stars for michael abraham, the guitar god who gave birth to explosive sound babies in everyone's ears last saturday night.

lXKjU1d7uy4aG0c5dNTATw.review_text: Dope spot in the Mission where you have anything you can ask for in this small, intimate space: free wifi, coffee, beers, diverse crowd, sangria, happy hour, spirits, ample seating, awesome atmosphere, heat lamps if the weather's chilly, great vibe, al fresco seating, friendly and cool staff, live jazz music, and food.  I'm a huge fan.

T-Nr9aVeIyEedh-Gr_xcbA.review_text: I feel 4.5 times cooler when I'm there.

fKrXlmBItmzNXFn6JD4d1w.review_text: If the revolution begins with trucker hats, copious tattoos, underground bloggers and the blasting of Neutral Milk Hotel and the like on the sound system, then the Revolution Cafe is indeed a catalyst for an overthrow of the system.   If the revolution involves lounging in a prime people watching spot in the Mission, sitting on the sidewalk and drinking Chimay on tap while the sun shines down upon you, then sign me up! I'm so there.  The Revolution cafe may not be fomenting dissent (other than your garden variety Mission-ite angst and disapproval) but it is a great place to hang out. You will need to dust off your table sharking skills and have an appreciation for, or at least a tolerance of, an eclectic variety of music . Don't expect the bartender to be social, that's not what he's there for. He's there to serve coffee, beer, wine, sometimes eats. They have Chimay on tap (did I mention that already?), a good wine selection, decent prices and generous pours.   Viva la revolution!

gn50Bb0tqy0nzHIJ947SNA.review_text: Honestly, I didn't try the food or the cofee... I went in to get change for a dollar. However, as I'm acutely aware of what has free wifi and what doesn't I was thrilled to find another cafe with free wifi that ALSO has great outdoor space.   Downside: During my five minutes in there, I couldn't avoid the overwhelming scent of B.O. I even checked myself - it wasn't me. And while I know, the scent of a hard working body is normal, it was just a little worrisome that the scnet was SO strong when the doors and windows were open...............  Needless to say, I'd go back for the free wifi and to taste the coffee, but only if it's nice out so I can sit outside in the "fresh" air.

ijpRP-xcbAtzE-Y-EVjEhg.review_text: Hipsters, weed-smockers, yuppy bohemians in one boat. + some random musicians. + sometimes this place smells funny, so betta sit outside.

f6aKthONslT3IM9KuXDIcQ.review_text: I love the environment, the food, and drinks! However, more painting and renewal of the furniture would make Revolution look a lot better.

lvkJL4jKF42oRyMYuZjK3A.review_text: This place kicks ass. At night at least.  Come when they have live music, its usually local. I love the rustic, kitschy vibe and I love the outdoor sidewalk seating...  Try the sangria, but don't come here to do shots and don't come in huge groups. Bring a couple chatty friends, sip on some drinks, enjoy the music and atmosphere.

pY0fmkxXB6VRmyEKHV0b3Q.review_text: I love this place.  I am not sure that it's totally "hipster" as others are calling it, it is more of a neighborhood place, kinda european, kinda hippie, kinda hipster also.   Great atmosphere, live jazz, good food, and the coffee is OK (not great, go to ritual instead).  The fact that they have an indoor/outdoor area, free live music makes it a great place.  22nd street!

dldq9nx2lCmku6PKBeTtCw.review_text: Seemed like a cool place, but I came at the asscrack time after happy hour and before the live music. I don't know if it was my friend's error or yelp's or the restaurant's website's error, but somehow happy hour ended an hour earlier than I was told. On top of that, most of the beers on tap were "out", wtf?? The waitstaff seemed overworked and confused, and got snappy at my friends while they were ordering. And there were some people hanging out working on their laptops with headphones on at 6:30 pm on a friday as most of the bar/cafe was clearly in party mode... just seemed odd. That said, the vibe was pretty good and the live music seemed like it would have been cool.  I can't decide if I will return here. It has potential, but the waitstaff need to work on their speed/attitude and the bar needs to be better stocked (managerial shittiness could be to blame for this, too).

zJJZv6nC7kOkhbAFhKXwhw.review_text: It has been awhile since I've been to a great cafe. The Revolution definitely surpasses my expectations. Reminds me of the local hangouts in Guanajuato and DF, despite the Brazilian music humming in the background. Right now I'm enjoying an iced cup of coffee (black), sandwiched between an international group and an old black piano. Random states are plastered on the top of a wee wooden table on which my drink and mcat book fit perfectly. And did I mention it's open-air?! Yup I'm happy.

kX7v9yOAs-BZ86zAldZC9Q.review_text: Revolution Cafe manages to bring together very diverse groups of people you wouldn't normally see together; it is like the fusion of yin and yang.  Whether its coffee or beer, Mission hipster or Marina local, Revolution serves up an interesting people-watching experience in an atmosphere of inclusion.  The music can be eclectic as well; I listened to a guy playing a washboard, water jugs and his own cheeks (yes, he was, in fact, slapping his own cheeks in rhythm - ouch!).  This is not a quiet place by any means, nor is it necessarily service oriented, but you will experience something which is uniquely San Francisco.

lX89A57ZsdTGx2BXaVLlYQ.review_text: Have you ever sat at Revolution with a great friend, a bottle of wine, a crisp summer evening, and just breezed away the time?  Hours pass, seeming like minutes, and you are none the wiser?  In Basque we have a saying, "Denbora badoa eta gu harekin"  ...."  time goes by, and we go with it"  And so it goes.

PAGIppDXVg12CyCa-gdLoA.review_text: I'm seeing signs of the the global financial crisis everywhere these days. As we approached Revolution Cafe, a diminutive hipster fellow got up from the patio table where he was doing whatever it is hipsters do on their $3000 mac book pros, and proceeded to beg the cashier for a job. Apparently they might even be able to use his help. Viva la revolución, the financial crisis is even getting the hipsters looking for gainful employment!   So about the cafe: I came here today for lunch and I have to say its a pretty cool place with some decent food and coffee. 2 grilled sandwiches + 1 latte + 1 double mocha = $20 = good deal!  I hear the night life can be pretty cool here.

gvQCzJO8LGIyLNnARr-IJg.review_text: Best described as the place that smells like weed, because there are always old people smoking weed outside. I think they might work there. Abercrombie (that store that used to exist) used to spray cologne or perfume outside their stores to presumably draw in more douche bags. Revolution Cafe has their own take on that - with the old people outside always smoking weed. It smells like good weed.   But seriously (I was serious above, too), Revolution is a quiet little place that's perfect for killing time relaxing with a beer, glass of wine or sangria. And there's some culture there, like the old folks outside smoking weed or the random hippie writing who knows what in her journal.   Service is great. Everyone is nice.

LKpd28drREu-cHwflED0TQ.review_text: Okay coffee, like the styling, the "old time" look, the open front.

W3RNKcZqRts5cme4qppwUA.review_text: Can't help myself...I love this place.

G1orIU7h-s8KOf1_2PNq5g.review_text: We were looking for a place to get coffee and a beer after a long day of Flea marketing. The reviews said this place was busy but it must depend on the time you go. We went about 4:45 on a Saturday and were able to find a nice place outside. However, when we walked back by later at night it was packed.   They have a few good beers on tap and the people watching was good because there are definitely some characters hanging around there! we didn't get coffee just a beer so I can not attest to coffee skills.  The tables were a little sticky even after we wiped it down with a cloth. But, if you want a beer (4.00 during Happy Hour) and some people watching before you move along with your night it was a good place.   A note for the Vegans! They have slices of Vegan pizza next door on the weekends till 5. It was cheap and decently tasty.

Sz2GHgbF4wJsP0n7t5MTtw.review_text: Dig the bohemian style.  Cool, man, cool.  This is one of those places that is a constant.  It is what it is.  Good coffee, good people, good service, good atmosphere.  Everything is good, and generally nothing is over the top.  Except for the live music.  I love me some of that.    Last night, we were up late working at the yoga shop, and some of our painters wanted coffee.  I thought: "Who on earth is still serving coffee around here at close to midnight?  Cafe Revolution!  So, I walked two blocks and braved the very crowed Classical Music Night to get some.  I was informed that the don't do coffee that late generally, especially since the steamer makes a lot of noise and would interrupt the flow of the musicians.  Fair enough.  But, the very nice man behind the counter offered to make a simple pot of coffee, and even made sure I had a carrier to get the goods back safely.  Good thing he had a carrier, because they were out of lids.  D'oh!  But, I made do, and all was well.    Cafe Revolution is indeed a hip place, with folks who are willing to do what they've got to do to make a girl happy.  Thanks.

c4mkYDTjJc-_lOM32YaPPQ.review_text: I wanted to sit and get some work done, my partner wanted to sit and have a drink.  What to do?  Well, we came here.  It was (very!) crowded, but we managed to find a table.  I got a tea and my partner had a beer.  I got work done.  Success, right?  Oh no, it gets better.  There was going to be live music!  Yay, live classical music!  And hell, one of the people playing was someone we knew (so random!).  The only reason it doesn't get 5 stars is that I had to wait for like 10 minutes to get more hot water for my tea.  The bartender spent a good fraction of that time attending to someone who wanted to order a lot of things this place didn't actually have.  And then helped lots of people who hadn't been waiting as long.

sR0I3N5q58Ne5EysyvZkPw.review_text: THIS PLACE OFFERS LIVE MUSIC.  From jazz, swing, blue-grass, circus music, blues, and everything in-between you will find it here.  Good luck in getting a seat though as this place is always popping with a very eccentric and friendly crowd.    I guess you probably wouldn't like this place if you were a Republican.  I guess a Ron Paul follower would dig it :)

KH2qUdGfLVap6A3kaOgWFg.review_text: The are many perks and downfalls to this neighborhood cafe. You may wait a moment to be acknowledged by the barista, but they're sincere and friendly when they do take your oder. Depending on the time of day, you may have trouble finding a seat. Lots of power outlets for laptops, a big plus for me. Music is always playing loudly and if you're lucky you'll catch one of the live bands that frequent this spot. After 3pm people are allowed to smoke on the patio, so sometimes the scent of cigarettes wafts in. On the plus side, they're pretty laid back about mary jane, a big plus in my opinion. Due to this, some seedy characters hang around the front of the cafe. Once, a drunk man seat-jacked me when I got up to grab something. I pointed to my laptop on the table and asked him to leave, but he refused and started spilling coffee all over. There was nowehere else to sit, so I had to pack up my things and go home, sadly.  I come here to work when I want to be distracted. Simply put, I haven't found another Cafe in the Mission to replace it's bohemian charm.

fgzhjAmeRnJiaDKLtWAN-g.review_text: Always packed, but nice open setting, and great live jazz/blues (wish they would play longer).  It's coffee and light food in the day, bar at night.  And free wifi.

-gJJzPghhC_gwHT-D8wlKQ.review_text: Great little place, that's Open late. we managed to squeeze a group of 10 around a table the size of a medium pizza. There was live music, and I taught the new bartender how to make a mimosa.

mnv-Z2vCfGffzvIV61q20A.review_text: It is busy.  All the time.  Literally.  But, if you get in, and the weather is nice, and people are smiling, there is no place i would rather go.  I love the different groups of people that feel welcome here.    I love places where you can get a few drinks for around $10 in an environment that is vibrant, yet where you can just sit and dish.

HWTOELslgXUrsgMOj9T9oA.review_text: I've only been hear during the day and i love it. I love how open it is, and on a warm day, its one of my favorite places to be in San Francisco. The atmosphere is super chill, just a lot of people hanging out, reading, on their computer, whatever. its great. The food is good, but this place is mostly about the atmosphere. As a bar, I have no idea, but any weekday for lunch, I would highly suggest this place.

36FHNVk0VWNSPh4Gm6zLEg.review_text: Since our group of four was able to secure a table, we had a great, mellow time drinking a few of good beer selection. They also had a number of wines and coffee drinks to choose from, but just enjoyed the beers. Also enjoyed the fact Revolution is open to the outside, so we got to enjoy the fresh air.

FnDttHrOrL-KADXxbeVeLQ.review_text: Some history: This used to be a flower shop back in the day (80's-late 90's) and I would go there to pick up a rose for my Valentine during my Middle School days-okay on to the review.....  Cool coffee shop. Good:  The live bands that perform              Having a good conversation with a stranger             People watching              Bad:   Hella crowded           Hella crowded           Hella crowded

DvZJEsVT3xeLhE4ZxWkZ1A.review_text: I've been coming to this place ever since I moved to San francisco, I guess its highlight has always been the great vibe, energy and chilled people that are here including the bartenders, however last night ( thursday ) I encountered this girl that was bar-tending at revolution cafe.  I gotta say I have been to many different bars in Sf and this one girl has to be the worst bartender here, not only was she rude to me but also to my friends in a  very condescending manner. Maybe in her latin country she can pretty much pull this off but not in SF girl :)    We where asking ourselves if this girl was PMsing that night?.  Me and my buddies will not  be coming back for a while now I hope she gets fired.

qxC3xdg8UUKdNK9cisEmAg.review_text: Papa Toby's Revolution Cafe is a little bit of Europe in the Mission. Come sit at one of the sidewalk tables, sip a latte, wine (sangria, too!) or ice cold beer. Read a book, hold a conversation or just idly watch the world go by. There's also a lite menu, if you're feeling peckish.

j763s4nxDBg_uNLk3N2WtA.review_text: Great place to hang out on Saturday afternoon when you're trying to plan the evening's adventures.  It's small, but there was a jazz duo playing and the vibe was good.  They ran out of Chimay glasses, so the bartender poured me a nice large pint.  Not a bad way to start.  Good coffee too for when you realized you've drank too many Chimay's on an empty stomach and will not last the night at the current pace...

VQ-AuyPD-MN91_DqqL6c0g.review_text: Good tunes.. Indoor outdoor space.. Spliffs light the evening air.. DJs, live music and more... Take your time getting there and get lost while you're there for sure stay awhile and capture the essence.

2HyocM--df01DOqP3IaD2A.review_text: I love this cafe. I never review a place I haven't frequented just to make sure I get it right.   You can sit outside and smoke and on a hot day it feels amazing! The crowd is definitely across the board, in a good way. Prices are good, music is always good.

8hh50iYCCPaMYZcRREG46A.review_text: Great for kickin' back and people watching on a sunny afternoon. Lots of typical Mission hipster/arty types. Dude behind the counter has strong opinions about the "best string string quartet in the bay" and I find that amusing. San Francisco and the Bay area in general need more open air cafes like this.

m3MkqidMw_8k4QJMyX53vg.review_text: If it wasn't for the sandwiches being completely amazing, this place would receive one star.  Their ham and cheese is made with blue cheese and is grilled to perfection and served warm....so tasty on a cold day!  The reason for the 2 stars is the staff and the time involved.  Don't come here for lunch unless you plan on spending the majority of your afternoon waiting for your sandwich.  Maybe the food tastes so good because by the time they get it to you, you would be content with dog food just to survive another minute.  The staff couldn't care less about customer service and they don't try to hide the fact.  They make you feel like they're doing you a favor by making your food and accepting your cash.  Call your order in 30 minutes ahead of time, pick up your ham and cheese, and get out as quickly as possible to get the most possible enjoyment out of this establishment!

PAFjVuEI0UwAUBl6xhLYkQ.review_text: "Best place to inhale second hand pot smoke." If that were a Bay Guardian "best of" category, this place would win. However, there is still something appealing about this place. I love that the front opens up to the sidewalk, and all kinds of people from all over the world seem to gather here. I think the main draw to this place isn't the food or wine/beer, it's more the scene. It's really entertaining to sit and have a glass of wine and watch people. There are crazies, artists, musicians, drop-outs, and I dare say a revolutionary or two. Wine and beer are affordable and it's a good spot to sit while you wait for a table at Lolo.

es3lKKd_APbnkxI7MFhW7A.review_text: A mere block from my apartment, I'm usually elbowing my way through the smoky throng of disaffected, unwashed 20-somethings overflowing out of this place.  When all the simpering hipsters realize that Boogaloos is closed for the day, they walk over here to be seen.  How do all these dirty unkempt people support themselves in this city?  It's a profound mystery.  Anyway, it was pretty much what I expected.  Smoky, boozy, counter-culture-y.  I was really tempted to play their piano.  And... that's about it.

CMUb2-7TkU1bWpQtKOOwUA.review_text: French friend were in town, and I was looking for a chill spot on a Saturday night that would also please them. Found Revolution Cafe and it couldn't have been more perfect. A spot opened up for us just as we arrived (it was fate!), we ordered a cheap liter of delicious Sangria, and had just enough time to chat and people watch outside before the band started playing. It was great!   The place feels tiny once the band gets going, but as more people pack in, it starts to feel cozy. You make friends with your neighbors (as per usual in California). The front porch on the street feels very European, like the sidewalk cafes of Paris, minus the smokers.   I can't wait to come back!

CFxhpHPGvlb9kInyJSn25w.review_text: Lovely place to smoke and drink coffee.  Some people might object to the full-on irony-free attitude.  But I'm just glad those a** **ts aren't taking up precious space under the heat lamp.  Minus one star because yoube panhandled.  But give it back because that's really your fault for giving away free money isn't it?

wM6ivcWBQNhKm4IurI2w5g.review_text: Love this place. They have coffee, tea, wine, beer, and live music. Oh, and candles. What else do you need to have a good time? Go around 8pm to secure a good seat and wait for the band! Friendly staff. Cash only!

-qDiotF8Qd0ThdLNEpg9Aw.review_text: It was a rare sultry November night in the City. The Mission was buzzing, and everyone was looking for a nice spacious patio where they could drink their beer under a starry sky.   Of course, nights like these mean Zeitgeist has a line out the door before 10pm. So where's a good-natured young lad to go to enjoy the weather and his suds? The answer lies on 22nd St., at Revolution Cafe.   Inexplicably, I'd never been to the 22nd St. corridor. Makeout Room, Latin American Club, these places had eluded me. But on that Friday evening, I discovered the majesty of Revolution: its throngs spilling out onto the sidewalk, drinks in hand; the air heightened with conversation; the piano trilling behind it all. I've never imbided in Paris, but I imagine this is the kind of casual elegance one finds there.   Somehow, Revolution has cultivated its popularity without becoming a scene -- that's more than I can say for Zeitgeist, unfortunately. And that's why I will return to this establishment again and again.

jWogrkf0PMfP9UoiXULKuw.review_text: When I think of places that somewhat sum up my idea of the Mission, this is one of them.  You got the quirky artwork on the walls, the eclectic staff, the bar-cafe fusion (decent beers -- leffe, chimay, etc), the daily independent musicians that entertain you from day til night. The diverse crowd may be my favorite -- dads taking their kids out for the day, the regulars blazing on the patio (and by regulars I mean, by my own labeling, the vietnam vet, the dreadlock boys, the rasta man, the knitting girl, etc), the teens scoping out the music, the old men reading their book/papers, and me, never really bored there. It's not the type of spot you come to have an amazing cup of coffee or a fantastic sandwich. It's more about feeling like you're in the hood and part of the hood if you're not so self conscious about everything going on.   I'm a fan of this place.

NoHJb7x8IEakUJTx6_vGTA.review_text: The city is littered with bars, but this place stands out. Amazing selection - tea, coffee, beer, hard liquor, and there's always someone with herbal remedies around the corner. The best part about this place: live music. Additionally, I really enjoy the patrons to this place.   It's definitely a place to start a night with - but not a destination, that's for sure. Seating can be a bit of a challenge, at best, and negotiating placing four people in one small area can be tiresome even for the most dedicated. :)

r0N7ck7_quS_kvh9JEmfWw.review_text: Quintessential Mission District cafe - very Cuban and the only great place to smoke on the veranda and listen to string quartets while you write in the evening over wine.

mcd0dpj7EzJfQWfeZSfyhg.review_text: i like.... but i'm not one of the cool kids. :*|  but damn there are some sexy men here. s***. and the sangria is good, wine is pricey, bathroom line, loooong on busy nights.

grQfs3DN2CHgzphRXssgCA.review_text: Great food, fresh coffee cake was pretty amazing. Service the day I went was a bit off; waiter had a problem with coming back to my table to refill my coffee. But overall a great place! Will always go when I have 2 hours to wait in line .  ;-)

Gy940qP1NXAQO2uXmnDOjg.review_text: The atmosphere of this place was great. I loved how it was laid back and I could float in and out (plus it was a warm night, so they had the doors open).   I had some pals playing the night I went. Of course they were the bomb diggity. Love me the jazz.  FYI - They only serve beer and wine. Food - Delish. I had a grilled cheese sammich. Bartender - I had to waive her down to get her attention. Plus, she gave me change for a $10 when I gave her a $20....TWICE. So check your change people!

pSms5uzIwl_eM6Gi7vVFYQ.review_text: Went here following a friend's recommendation but was very unimpressed. The smell of pot was wafting in the air, the tables were all sticky with previous patrons' beverages, and the wine list was really, really short. No need to go back.

z9QUB1QIaMWCeeGkpldMbA.review_text: worst bar tender. ever.  i generally like my bars to be a little gritty with a slight stale aroma, in fact, i prefer them that way.  what i have zero tolerance for is a bar tender who rudely and wrongly tells me that my table is not tipping and tries to up-charge me on my order ("it would be $15 but i am going to charge you $20").  firstly, a tip is gratuity for good service not a right; and secondly,  all members in my party were once in the service industry and all tipped.  get your facts straight before you start making accusations.   tip for the long haired bar tender - don't be a dick.  i really liked the ambiance and the scene there but the sour apple brought the whole experience down.

Y4UyTU6qKd2-WdRf724QjQ.review_text: Took a girl here a few months ago after dinner in the Mission.  They have a good selection of beer and wine.  Navigated through a crowd of people of find a couple of seats.  Nothing gets better than enjoying some live music and a glass of wine.   Atmosphere is kind of loud, I found myself having to yell to have a conversation.

K8nkgNBRnx7G7Umt-zmP9g.review_text: Revolution Cafe, oh how I miss thee!!! From drunken mid-day lunches shared with good friends and pitchers of sangria, to more quiet study sessions in the early morning. This was my favorite spot when I was in college and worked in the mission!     They have great coffee, good salads and a great beer selection.   Worth the visit if you're in the area!

eurIEcpGa_tTi1LMWa1pUA.review_text: In truth, I would have liked to give this place 3.5 stars, not four. The beers are pretty good, and there's a cool boho vibe that's not too pretentious (tough to find in the 'new' Mission).  The service during the day can be a little scarce, with the staff seeming like they have better things to do than actually serve you, such as chatting with their B/GF who's sipping a ginger latte at the bar. Try to get a sandwich at lunch and you may find yourself waiting 20+ mins. for a friggin' tuna melt.

oiBWUP7PijTkxZZQagT5KQ.review_text: +4 stars: Sitting in a lovely airy café sipping on a Hoegaarden with happy Mission people.  -1 star: Inhaling the pot smoke from nearby café groupies.

oOqzSVGKRYUQRpaXECfCmg.review_text: the service is terrible. i had a nicer review about a year ago, but had to amend it because it apparently has gotten exponentially worse.   an employee told me it would take ten-fifteen minutes to make a bagel with veggies on it. not because it took ten minutes to make, because she was stepping out for her cigarette break. really. i watched her tell me how long it would be, walk by me, sit outside and smoke a cigarette, then make the sandwich. thanks, but no thanks.

aVAAzlIdfXT9LZ4ICIgSBw.review_text: If you ever want to: -enjoy a good beer -meet new people -hear live music -people watch -feel like you landed on another happier planent then you should come here.   The food is decent but that's not the draw - it's the ambiance. Tea selection is meh. Steamed vanilla milk hits the spot. It usually looks really crowded, but there are always a few extra seats and I've never been turned down when I've asked to share a table.   Fun sightings from last time - people sharing a pot of soup outside, the musical bikers, people dancing in all of 4 square feet.

1y5jl7wdDoJ3RacNAcZreA.review_text: 4 1/2 STARS.  one of my top 3 cafes in SF. the only reason i'm not giving it a full 5 stars is because the location..its kind of out the way and i haven't tried any of the food. the atmo, the coffee, the art, the hood, the staff..it all screams San Francisco! In fact, for those of you who remember SF back in the day (early 90's), this place reminds me of what Horseshoe cafe was like on lower haight and steiner. PLUS, the last time i was there, they had happy hour $2 import drafts.  YUM!!! Nothing like coffee then beer. imported beer..on draft!

ZBLZIOrO3DZJzDFlFO-bJw.review_text: This is a great chill spot to have a drink and listen to some live jazz. I usually go here and order a pitcher of sangria and enjoy the evening with good friends. You can sit inside or outside. Drinks are inexpensive and the ambiance is right up my alley. You'll usually find people having some sort of intellectual conversation or even reading the communist manifesto (though slightly cliche) . It's a diverse crowd and I always feel very comfortable here.

B1AnBMTvBn48JPYCOp1G6A.review_text: Complete with pot smoking hipsters, stiff sangria, jazz bands, and awesome hummus. The French communist inspired aura that riddens this charming SF spot is too cool to have a sign in front. If you come accross the smell of herb and a red wooden star whilst walking down the mission district in your dark trench coat.... you've found the right place.

E-XwUol0CHWfURrVU-5GOw.review_text: Revolution Cafe is definitely one of a kind.  There's really no way to truly  describe it.  It's a cool place to hang out and just relax in the evening.  It's essentially the epitome of chill.  Stressed out?  Tired?  Don't want to think?  Go to Revolution Cafe.  Whether you're there to have a drink, do work, play some games, people watch or just listen to music, you really can't go wrong.  True, it tends to get crowded and relatively dark (enough where you can barely read the menu), but that's what I like about it.  Also, you have your option of indoor/outdoor seating.  And if you're like me, it's great place for grabbing a drink while waiting for your reservation in the Mission.

3xvG4A_VYtW3rvGuAvJPaQ.review_text: Been here a few times and love stopping in for a drink and a snack during beautiful San Francisco afternoons.  When I went last there was a great jazz band playing, which was hip and fun to listen to.  We munched on the humus with a bear for me and a mojito for the ladies.  This is what you would expect from the name.  A hip little cafe/bar with a lefty loosey feel.  And they have free wifi too.  A great stop when your in the Mission.

TgfvhtGxMKjlzLTuq6Hb4g.review_text: The Family Crest at Revolution Café, September 12, 2011 Part I Restorative surgery: American and Cuban pictures. A packed house, as usual. The blurts of a contained horn. Rhythm furnace. Hot, baked interlude of daylight simmering into night. I love black polka dots. The most beautiful eyes watch a bow go back and forth. Cat eyes. Mysterious eyes. Bedroom eyes. Shoulders smaller than forearms in her hand a flute. It turns out those eyes are leaving. Phone light in her face. The one with a bun in her hair plays the piano. Black dress; single shoulder straps barely an inch, then the lights descend. She motions a violinist into a space between tables. The voice whose sound I cannot recognize yet does a melodic test. Amid the chaos of back music, now guitar strums. Bun drops, the voice fills the air. My heart sinks, tears well at the beatific night. A man's voice; it's high, enchanting like a woman's call, androgynous. Strings, the pianist plays moving her bangs. "Night and day, I need you here." Melodic, majestic, "Watching and whatnot," he says. "Romeo and Juliet," the violin of yesteryear. High walls of orchestrated eloquence, telling a story of love, like Spencer Day. One voice organizes the others, a series of black outfits, strumming, blowing, dragging a bow; a voice fills the air, foot on a drum. Chorus. Tempered by the violin, acapella intro. "Nearby café, Listen closely and you'll hear the sound of breaking hearts." Family Crest. Aqualung, Dead Can Dance. Haunting ghoulish minstrels 31 shows in 31 nights, like gypsies for money, a xylophone. "I'll move through the night, I'll sleep when I am dead..." Irish River Dance. "Bells are Ringing Over the City." Storytellers dreaming otherworldly images. Part II Beethoven Violin Quartet #1 (I guess) From no sound to a particular sound, how once there is nothing, then a Beethoven I never would have guessed. She took off her glasses, elevator glances at the thin violinist, who can't see her in his arcing. "MJ179" is the violinist's name. (Small light brown curls, leather jacket, plaid shirt.) The complexity of the pieces is daunting, from memory-like typing where hand and eye coordination must fly, and where for me it would be problematic, never sure, perhaps by intuition looking at the letter forms. Schumann Piano Quintet. Yoshi's in October. Repeating the piano as a silhouette. They come in and out of prominence, as strings then as piano (also strings) the music translates to my own joy. I feel like I can play or at least have memory. These are like mist clouds over a green hill. I wonder if other animals respond in kind. When something doesn't go right, we seem to notice, like the last page of a piece. But what we do with empty space is up to us. Mendelssohn Violin II Quartet Opus 13 (youtube.com/watch?v=4hlv…) Interlocking in space. Each member playing his part. A flutter, seriousness, a graceful courtesy. A tender eyeing of the tenorous man, the bejeweled woman, a commotion of simultaneous notes, a conversation among strangers. I can't quite place the sound, whether a clothesline on a New England Beach in winter or feelings themselves. Is this water falling in a sink as the wife of a cheating man washes the dishes? Is this the sun rising on her empty bed? I hear the door opening. The woman's dog is feeling her sorrow. Her children are fast asleep. "Ellis and Gough... Classical Revolution CD." Much sadder and slower, this time the husband is home. Everything festers, where one seems free; the other is locked in the righteousness of commitment. They fight despite that flowers are given, yellow ones in the morning light, with the envy of innocence. The pure one wishes it could be less true. In fear, she surmises her hurt. He takes a shower. She hears the soap drop. Then the whole body seems to crash. A loss of consciousness comes over him. She weeps seeing her entre vous. She opens the door quickly and comes to his aid. He barely notices her, still in the water. He is quiet. He is alone, distant to himself under the auspices of time and memory. Philip Roth: American Pastoral, The Human Stain, The Plot Against America (Continuum Studies Contemporary N American Fiction), late Beethoven Quartet no.13 op.130, cavatina (5/8), best love music he ever wrote. Somehow she manages to forgive him and life seems to go back to normal. The dog's chain rattles as it sits on the floor. I wonder what it is feeling? Are these notes too sharp for its ears? Is it pleased? Still, a mood, walking home alone in the alley, between two streets, these haunting melodies come to the man. She has long ago left him. He is alone. All progress is over. Time has come. There is this tender moment he sees as he looks out the window and potential lovers are chatting.

JFLTI42KbX0mfPnG9rsGtQ.review_text: we went last night and there was a great band playing... a lot of hippies dancing and belly slapping and a lot of good vibes and fun in the air.  they have a delicious sangria, they had a diverse crowd and i liked how the bar opened up onto the front patio that opened up and spilled out onto the street.  kind of felt like a house party. this place reminds me a lot of new orleans - if only it were about 40 degrees hotter.

5FMsS5uiDVQSbM0dpwmcSw.review_text: A nice spot with decent beer selection and an okay attitude. I've never tried the food. Usually nice, local art on the walls and good live music. It has always been a bit too crowded when I've been there. I can agree with some people here finding it a bit overrated as a hipster-hangout though.

HRK7DiNSIfwo8giKah9ZyA.review_text: My friends and I were looking for a cafe or lounge with live music and decided to try to yelp a place and we found this gem! I don't drink so a lot of times I end up drinking a few club sodas and getting bored while by friends get drunk; or it's so crowded and loud, I can't enjoy the music. This place was perfect--I could have a great latte while my friends ordered Sangrias.   The latte was very good and not expensive. My friends complained that the Sangrias were more like grape juice and didn't have a lot of alcohol, but they didn't mind too much since the prices are pretty low.   My friends and I arrived at 9 pm on a Friday night and the place was almost full, but we were able to snag a table outside on the patio...right near the glass doors into the cafe. We saw the band come in around 9:15/9:30 and they started the performance near 10 pm. They played mostly Latin and Spanish music...it was very lively and sounded amazing. The place inside was super packed and very hot so we were happy to be outside and able to hear the music just fine. I could see some people dancing inside and enjoying themselves, even thought there isn't really a dance floor.   The only downside of sitting outside is that smell of cigarettes and pot. If you mind those two things then I would suggest you sit inside. I thought it was a great experience and very SF--hippies, hipsters, and bums all converging in one area. Also, CASH ONLY (bummer).

ZFqxfWN0XemGc0vTvzL3GQ.review_text: I used to like this place because you could grab a beer, enjoy the sunshine and chat with an interesting crowd.   Now that crowd has become increasingly self-absorbed and hostile along with their service.  Too bad.

hKozw4Wo1DAXtBomsqRCxQ.review_text: Tandem reviews .... well, after Momi Toby, let's talk about Papa Toby....  This is definitely the better location of the Toby empire. There's not much to write home about the food or drink there, but it's decent. The reason to go there is because armed with a book or notebook, you can while away an entire afternoon or even day in blissful relaxation, watching folks, listening to music and smoothly progressing from your morning tea to your afternoon alcohol.  There aren't enough places like that in the city.

fmND2SiyAjxt3tcg4uwAGQ.review_text: It's nice to come here before the post dinner crowd, and the band starts, which is Saturdays, I believe. They're lenient about sitting inside with small dogs too, which is nice. I sat down with a beer with a dog I was caring for snoozing in my lap and wrote for hours until it got super loud and crowded, which was around 10-11. Great for people watching if you're a writer like me and don't mind the dim lighting, or sitting facing the sidewalk, much like a theater.

7cK2PLHbdUx-eY-Pp7UTKg.review_text: Revolution Cafe stops short of 4 stars due to the snail pace of the counter staff and the food quality.  I receives 3 stars for a number of reasons:  1. Outdoor seating, a rarity in the mission (which explains why this place is always PACKED) 2. you can smoke (weed or cigarettes) on the porch and the sidewalk tables 3. completely dog friendly (a new requirement, but an important requirement nonetheless) 4. Reasonably priced alcohol and a good happy hour special.

Q22t5iM7_TjdYgbD-Ardbw.review_text: Open air cafe with live piano music, happy hour and a comfortable atmosphere. It has my vote.

nsawcqioX0NDmqsDsM8L4w.review_text: Cool spot with free wifi but not a cool spot at night to do work unless you are trying to seduce your computer.  Low light, Jazz playing, your computer would be say "(Insert your name) I love it when you turn me on"

84fywm01SmrXqyAB8UYgyA.review_text: I went there for breakfast this morning with my friend and my service dog. We were told we could only sit outside on account of the dog. I showed them my dogs service tags, they still showed us the porch.....what the? What kind of world do we live in anyways????? Don't go here.

9xCS-bF15j9pduE-tR8e-g.review_text: If you enjoy listening to the tunes of Manu Chao and St. Germaine, while sipping a tasty cup o' joe  [al fresco style], then this place is for YOU.  The caf has a pretty good variety of lunch items (I recommend the Blue Cheese & Apple Chicken salad) and expands their beverage menu way beyond the standard coffee house.  I was rather impressed with their wine selection and beer on tap.  If I lived in San Fran, I would most definitely frequent this joint...

GsxwryUiwVStIFmZ3lcmHA.review_text: Not a place for non-smokers, especially after dusk starts kicking in.  Nor is it a good place for folks afraid of cold [not helped by a lukewarm hot chocolate].  Or someone who wants some lighting when she reads or writes at night.  Unfortunately, I'm (d) all of the above.  You see, Revolution is essentially an open space, a room with an entire wall missing.  And the cafe clearly doesn't have enough money to pay its electricity bill.  Either that, or they were trying to set a mood.  Perhaps it's the latter, given that I heard someone passing by on the way to the restroom mention to the girl sitting next to me that his friend thought she was attractive.  What are we, kids at an awkward middle school dance?  That's what you'll have to deal with when you come here after dark.  Come armed (...with you trusty bodyguard - I don't condone weaponry).

bG6DkJKwhKMMQ0Z3GSOpmA.review_text: I've never been to Havana, but I HAVE been to the Revolution Cafe on a hot day, & it's felt close to what I'd imagine a Cafe in Havana must feel like.   A friend of mine lives directly above this cafe, & I met up with him for an afternoon drink last Saturday during Burning Man, when the city felt a step slower, a bit less crowded. We sat around for a few hours sipping coffee & beer & talking to some of the extremely friendly patrons. Music drifted through the place like a hazy plume of exhaled cigar smoke. Life was good.  This little block at this particular moment was fast making me re-realize the charms the Mission holds. The charms that had been lost between countless weekend nights spent barhopping & in that 15 minute wait to pee in the Delores Park bathroom on an insanely crowded warm sunny Sunday.  It's got everything a Mission community coffee shop SHOULD have: Good coffee, good sandwiches, sangria, beer, a spacious, airy & somewhat mysterious atmosphere. A living breathing consciousness that you just can't pin down.  The friend of another good friend from back East moved into town recently & got a place just a few blocks from the Revolution. He wanted to meet up & needed suggestions. Big surprise, I told him about this place & after a few hours drinking coffee & beer there yet again yesterday, I think I've got another convert.  The Revoution has already started.

0I0qNOiWbPeLPMRpfZtdIA.review_text: We were a couple of tired soles. Our souls were thirsting! We needed a place to get away from the bourgeoisie we had become and get in touch with our proletariat side. (Oohh I like that! must use over and over and over again!) Anyway, back to my story. What was it anyway?  So, it's around 80 degrees outside (scorching for SF!) and after walking from Puerto Alegre to the Sketcher's outlet we needed something to quench our thirst and please the palate. So we stop and decide to try out TRC. I've walked past this place many a time, each time getting a look from the patron's seated in front of this place that said to me, "Look at us! We're so smart, hip and beautiful."   So as we walk back to our cars from the Sketcher's Outlet and lugging our bags of slip-ons, and lace-up open-toe platforms (Okay, so Jen is gorgeous and bought these hot shoes which made her look even hotter! - ZIZZLEzzzzz! - I just had to get that in Jen! Anyway, marvelous simply marvelous! Oh lord, I felt so feminine saying that - fanning my self Ala Carl Lagerfeld)  Oh, so back to TRC, it was cool inside, lot's color and lot's of characters. It was like Smurfville meets, Gotham City! Robin Hood vs. Pinocchio. Never seen so many fedora's worn by 20 somethings in one place. Oh. yeah back to earth. We both ordered Italian sodas. Jen had Cherry and I ordered Mango/Banana. I've never seen so little sparkling soda mixed in with a bottle of syrup! I guess this is good. Anyway, the sodas were okay but the weather was so nice outside that I will give this place an extra star just because it was a part of my fabulous afternoon!  Why did I write this review?  Such a waste! Here, I'll give you a refund. Here you go, you just got the last 5 minutes (slow reader huh!) of your life back. Me, I'm  out a lunch hour at work (slow everything!). Serves you and me right for Yelping on the job! I'm about to get kicked out of Yelp so I better shut up!

anAhHwwGNSxvEW6IhFYGEw.review_text: My visit was short but sweet much like this review:  Cozy low key old school place, one of few with sidewalk seating in the city, nice for a beer and some good free live music, whether alone or with people, relaxing or working.   And while the live music was great, the triphop they were playing before it was even better. Somehow I felt like I was in Texas, not SF, which is kinda nice on a summer day.

mo_y_F7-JM4f4qu3HSn68g.review_text: I really like this spot, and have been coming here for years. However, I was so disappointed the other afternoon when I went to have a tea and a group of obnoxious white girls came and all started smoking pot. The woman working there would not ask them to stop or leave. Not everyone enjoys the smell of people smoking pot in a cafe.

U9yWtQO_0LPjtaU9jN0JsA.review_text: The Revolution Cafe is a very cool place but boy can it be crowded on the weekends.  I can see why, it's warm and cozy inside, there's live music playing.  Everyone's just chilling out.  However, it can be extremely difficult to make your way to the bar and even more difficult to find somewhere to stand.  Although it feels as if the cafe is spilling out onto the street, if you have a beer in hand you must be standing on their patio and not touching the sidewalk.  They don't have a sidewalk license yet and will have a bouncer outside enforcing this rule.  I would recommend coming on a weekday.

IpsYi0rOnYQ-Q0BBP9sJgQ.review_text: Great place to soak in sun, drink some beer, listen to live music and while away the hours on a lazy day.  Also, an amazing place to people watch or get into a conversation with a complete stranger.  Lacks some the pretension you run into in the mission.  Tip- check out the music on Sunday evenings, often graduates from the conservatory can be found playing interesting classical pieces.  The ginger latte is great when you are under the weather and don't want a beer.  Food isn't there strong point so I would skip it.

U13tLFucJNz1fNv_Xgdj0g.review_text: A cafe with no walls.  Literally.  I can get used to that (when those rare beautiful SF days roll around).  Otherwise, it's a bit chilly, but that's really the only flag.  Coffee, tea, beers on tap, they have it all, as well as musicians/artists hanging about doing their thing.  Definitely one of those places that personifies the Mission.

60i_IU1tpgU_6N2qKD9fCQ.review_text: The Rev is a test bar for me: if I meet someone who has been there and didn't dig it, I know the dissing party is most likely also guilty of douchebaggery and not worth my time.  Classical Sundays are a treat, as are the delish mimosas. Always a vibrant scene. Sometimes the pot truffle man circulates through the crowd. One of the 5 best bars in town.

_Kt01zAkzGDjSphy7W3qOA.review_text: I've always loved this place for it's casual atmosphere, eclectic and international crowd, open air patio and live music. I brought an out-of-town guest here after a stint at the Velvet Cantina and it proved the apertif. The jazz band was great and the wine was perfect- plus we happened to get there early enough to snag a table facing the performance. Thumbs up!

2LFR7OvCUH5nZR1P0VLemQ.review_text: New update:   Moving up from 4 stars to 5 stars. Its simply now one of my favorite places to go for live music and never any cover charges! Plus, the people are all very friendly, and laid back; its has a very genuine local Mission SF feel and hang out. I bring my guests from out of town so they can experience the culture here.   And the guy who was a little mean to some folks in the past is much nicer now (and to clarify he would only snap at folks who were in need of correction---now he does it professionally. The girl they had working there who recently left was also always super nice.   Lastly, the smokers now (obviously informed) are more considerate and do step out to the sidewalk mostly to smoke cigarettes so it no longer is a problem for those who want to to avoid breathing in smoke, inside.   ------------------------  Updated: They have a new person working there, and she is very nice.
