In fact all the people working here are quite nice. Also, the smoking problem apparently has been fixed. Rarely do I smell smoke from cigarettes (I actually like 420), coming in anymore. They seem to now enforce that, which is great. So changing this to a 4 stars. I would give it 5 except its so popular its hard to find a seat. :)  -----  I love it here because of the free music, including classical every Monday. The guy that works there can be a little rude, though, but that doesn't really bother me. What does bother me is all the smoke. Lots of smokers right outside in the patio (which seems like smoking is allowed there?), and all that smoke doesn't know to stay outside with the windows all open and the door open; the wind brings it right indoors. I thought SF had some strict smoking laws? If so they should really be enforced. My gf who I brought here to enjoy the music doesn't want to come back because she can't stand the smoke which was particularly strong that evening. Otherwise, everything else is good about this place, including the food.

v_9CqZOenNYhVZ5KT16bJw.review_text: Yay!  I love this place.  If you go Monday-Wednesday, you can actually find a small table to share with friends.  A great place to sit on a warm summer evening.    +5 stars for decent house sangria, good music, and good people watching -1 star for the espresso bar closing at 10pm.

FH_58ovtah1RPbamLxy4nw.review_text: all i had is wine. and a lot of fantasies over the bald moustachio barman ever since.

x1MlbcgTYx5dD-C6LYDwHw.review_text: I lived on 22nd St. for years, and have seen this place go through changes (good & bad). Just stopped by this week. My current assessment.  Pros: - Open air, sidewalk seating like a cafe should - I've seen a few good live shows here  Cons: - Dirty and unkempt - Stereotypical, airhead hipster working the counter like a salted snail - Sangria = a full fruit cup glass with a dash of wine

aUPVDSaLeBvd-iv9ZG12vg.review_text: Pretty underwhelming, I'd say.  I mean yes, it is cool, it is happening, it is full of life and "personality." But it's also loud, hard to find a seat, and the beer is expensive (cheapest is $4).  A good place to meet up with friends, but I wouldn't come here on my own. Despite that, there were tons of people who did come alone and took up one of the very few tables available all for themselves. Indifferent service.  Exactly as Yelp says: "Meh. I've experienced better."

Xj0O2l0bp633ebmG468aZw.review_text: The coffee is good. The crowd is hipster-friendly and conducive to ramblings, making the environment almost great.  Free jazz is always good. The African theme is OK, but not fleshed out. Would be a regular there if I were in the hood.

bPLL3tqfwBrRX0K5dwgONw.review_text: It's a funny thing to see people heading over here with cups of coffee from Ritual. And the only reason that isn't me is because I'm a poor pathetic wino and I originally came here for the booze. But that pretty much about says it all, doesn't it? Revolution provides the best environment for you to enjoy the best coffee. The fusion of these two would be explosively mind-boggling but life isn't really in the business of being too good to you. No need to venture too far and wide for the ying and the yang though, they're both within walking distance of each other.

gM1X8z0XdjZHYUquF13SNA.review_text: A selection of wines, local and european beers, a warm and friendly welcome ... the perfect place when you just landed and want to rub a little to the local wildlife.  Excellent live music some nights too!

HMFf6rvXuW4TV21Hbd8doQ.review_text: There is nothing like spending a lazy Saturday afternoon at this place drinking sangria. I like sitting outside reading a book or just people watching. It is a great place to come by oneself or with friends. Highly recommended!

5PqydQO0AhSul4vvWcKv7A.review_text: Being that my brother works in the Mission and I was meeting him for lunch... he suggested that we go to Revolution Cafe.  I loved that it was a quasi outdoor place that was hip and for the locals.  People were eating with others or just by their lonesome reading a book while sipping on their coffee.  We had a bottle of wine and I ate the marinated pork sandwich.  I'd have to say that it was THE BEST pork sandwich I've laid my lips upon, ever!  The meat was tender and the bread was heated to perfection.  A bit of a while to wait... but it's expected since the place fills up quickly.

RNE1HBMTUWD5TA0F5dLgMg.review_text: Nice atmosphere and a good alternative to the packed, drink spilling scene that generally ensues elsewhere.  Not to say this place doesn't get cozy, but you're less likely to have a toe smashed or come out with beer stains.  I usually enjoy a few Chimays, some conversation, likely in Spanish, watch people swing dance or catch a live performance.  It never feels scenster or too cramped, I've frequently witnessed and experienced people's paths crossing at this little tucked away joint.

2gV1sQgDbZHOvfPaewbYZg.review_text: It doesn't get more hipster-Mission than this.  Multi-ethnic, crowded, local, outdoor seating, large selection of beer, a few tasty snacks, marijuana smoke, scribbling on the walls, old Hispanic man writing his memoirs while surrounded by stoned white people with unwashed hair, etc  Warm summer nights this place is packed to the brink and the crowd spills out on the sidewalk and forms a quasi-street-party.  If you like the spirit of hipster-Mission, you'll like this. Period.

BvfLMRoP_-I1q3sjdDCQZg.review_text: I absolutely LOVED this place.  Loved the energy, the people, the drinks, Great music - and the colorful crowd around us.   ( if you are not open-minded, and get offended when people are smoking up  - probably not a good place for you )  We came for HH, and sat outside. Ordered a few pitchers of Sangria, and chit-chatted with the locals.  People were dancing around us, and singing and all kinds of happiness.   Had a lovely time - I really enjoyed myself.  Great for a warm sunny day :)

sRorz0Qgn5SrHr3Z8FElAQ.review_text: Decent food. Drinks. Heat lamps. Smoking outside. Art inside. Live jazz sometimes. Not super expensive. Good location. Scoring a good seat is crucial. The hip crowd is usually between 25 and 35. Hit the nearby Latin American Club before or after.

LGufIIeU8dnKwIInM3eZ0g.review_text: I'm in love with this Sunday Funday-evening hot spot.  I was here last night with a friend and we watched a quartet over Chimay's. So San Francisco and such a perfect way to end a great weekend.  I'll definitely be back!

Kx9zqQ_QA9lpN0fwWrgK7w.review_text: A cool place in the Mission that had a nice mix of beers, wine, coffee, sandwiches, etc.  I was disappointed by the hot chocolate (the powdered kind) which was thin, but the place accommodated beer, wine, and the non-drinkers among us.

K2T07KsJ7CxJq2eBhu5SuA.review_text: This review really depends on WHY you go there.  See, I work in an office right across the street, so for me, it's a convenient place to get coffee in the morning.  Unfortunately for me, it probably has the worst coffee of any cafe in the city.  Their espresso is even worse.  Plus, they don't open until 9 or so, and sometimes they're not even open then.  Having said that, I do really like the ambiance, and they have good food.  Sometimes when I leave the office at night, the place is popping with music and a huge crowd.  So if you're going there for lunch or to drink, it's probably a nice spot.  Just not for morning coffee.

RpAIjUSDcKHh8fXJxZVqDw.review_text: I'm disappointed by this place. I was in the area looking for a bar, came in here because they advertised mixed drinks. When I asked the bartender he said they don't really have a liquor license so they don't really make those. So..... why put it on the menu?

LzsFT_Bg1J-cHUd4WTcf0g.review_text: this place is amazing.  it reminds me of europe.  everyone is speaking different languages, they have leffe beer on tap, and their sangria is simple but awesome.  and the outdoor patio is more than a girl could hope for.  i had a sandwich there one, a veggie sandwich of some sort, and it was really good too but i mostly go for the ambiance.

_LuUja6q_ClLj157y4XMqg.review_text: Best place in town for a beer on a Sunday afternoon while listening to some jazz!

K5YW4SQjestLSJbm4pa8OA.review_text: Just topped in for a drink before our flight out of San Fran.  It was recommended by a friend, and well worth it!  The odd shaped pillows were fun to play with & their beer-on-tap selection was not bad at all.  Sadly they were out of Sangria (cuz we wanted a huge pitcher of it)... oh well, will have to go back the next time we are in SF.

l795RBCdhpRyLvrsxp85HA.review_text: This is a great place, except the bartender.  There is a tall guy who's attitude seems to be higher then everest.  I saw him complaining to a costumer for not leaving a BIG enough tip. Also its very community oriented place and everyone is kinda seating together, so he comes out and calls people   junkies,  the irony is that he himself looking like he just came back from the rehab.  If I would be an owner I would consider to fire him.

mmNjmSHNlEgSccs5vCIwIQ.review_text: After a great brunch over at Spork we were looking for a cafe to hang out at and maybe get a few things done before heading over to the annual BYOBW race that's held every year on Easter Sunday. Last year I lamented missing it because my friend was taking too long to get ready. By the time we showed up it was over and I was sad :-( I swore that "next year I'm going for sure".  Welp, like any good Cleveland Indians fan knows (I happen to be one), "next year's the year" for me for sure because I missed the damn BYOBW race yet again :-)   It was raining so hard outside we just chilled inside safe from the cats and dogs falling from above. Instead we found ourselves unable to leave and soaked up the wonderful music on this rainy Sunday afternoon.  Looking forward to coming back here another time for a great environment and some great music!

VYNdpH4i51StwGMdSEZDiA.review_text: free wifi, outdoor seating, beer, wine, and of course coffee   beagles, croissants, sandwiches, and snacks are all pretty yummy. The sandwiches come with a little green salad and are a little pricey, but they are very tasty and have some delicious combinations.    The atmosphere is very laid back and there are a lot of regulars. its slower during the mornings and early afternoon, but the place packs in after 5.

yFkz0xJklnRk6xw6vyGNCg.review_text: A nice spot to indulge in some Interneting and take advantage of their generous happy hour (3-6 daily), especially on sunny days.  Decent food as well.    One star off for the unsupervised kids and dogs who nearly knocked over my table twice one recent Sunday afternoon (I generally like both kids and dogs, btw) and the table-hoarding habits of some patrons.

CShpbzQyU59Ev8VkIHUWsA.review_text: One of the places I frequented when I first moved to the bay area was Revolution Cafe. It's the perfect way to catch the diversity of San Francisco locals. It's a multipurpose open space with small tables like a local European cafe.  Most of the tables are crowded towards the open area and people are spilling to the sidewalk. It certainly feels busy all the time, but not over crowded (although it may take you some time to grab a seat or two) but that just gives you an excuse to bump into someone and start a conversation.  The music varies, much like the people. Music can be loud and in your face or chilled back, much like the people. The atmosphere is always cool and it's always fun to just sit back and watch it all unfold. The beer is good and flowing, the coffee is decent. They have some food, but not spectacular. It's good to snack on while drinking your Chimay. You can bring your laptop or a book, or just bring yourself.  The only bummer is that there's one bathroom, but that's quickly overlooked by the indescribable coolness of the place. What a great way to start getting to know this city.

FSyDuThc76rNcwBzcKq7cQ.review_text: Not my revolution but maybe someone else's. I was surrounded by pregant ladies rubbing their bellies - over and over. People immersed in their laptops. Smells of incense, weed and American Spirit cigarettes. And one pesky gnat - or maybe a whole gang of them taking turns- hovering around my beer and guacamole.

xJXvHd-cwNvo4eGemk7JKw.review_text: Love this place. I've been coming here for years.   The vibe is great, the music is always amazing, and the beer is flowing. Sangria's not bad either.   The bands they get here are world class. No kidding. Monday night latin jazz will shake your hips. Saturday/Sunday jazz bands are best in the city. Best of all, it's free- but don't forget to tip the band and get a drink!  The atmosphere attracts ALL types of people. A city for all and a place for all. I've seen all walks of life hanging out and grooving to the music here. Rarely does a place create a place where everyone can be together, and there's no place else in the city like it. You wanna make a friend, meet some strangers, share with a foreigner, talk to someone in a different language - this is your spot.   I see some negative reviews about the staff - definitely take those with a grain of salt. The staff is pretty rad. Yeah, if you don't buy something, they'll get upset, but who goes to a bar and doesn't buy nothing? That's just loitering. And the neighborhood attracts some riff raff, so it's nice to see some of the employees take a stand against some of the BS that happens on this corner.   But, did I mention the jazz? So good.

3zyBvSsgLEWYsPpnFIxV2g.review_text: It's hard to know what you are going to get when you come here, which is good if you are open-minded, and maybe not so good if you're a prick.   Let's just say:  One Day, 7:30 pm Thursday, hip hop lady rapper is spitting some ill beats with fellow dreadlock companions about living in the mission. Lots of people are outside smoking cigarettes, drinking beer, and loving it.   Some other day around 1pm Sunday, ordered two delicious mighty leaf teas, luckily got a table, yet extremely close to everyone around us, listened to very loud jazz music that was pretty awesome and still could sort of have a conversation.  Another day at the cafe, 3pm Monday, barely any people, got a great seat, ordered a delicious chai latte, read and people watched until 5pm. Later on that day, started to get full of people having beers and funky conversations.  Last day so far at 10am Friday, cup of coffee, the newspaper, outside under the heat lamps working on my laptop and feeling welcomed by the neighbors.   Considering these experiences here is some advice: stick to beer, tea, wine, or lattes, experiment with the food (it's a little different every time someone different is working), and  expect a somewhat eccentric, yet laid-back atmosphere.

qlJVwqTNPKDv91NOfi0k9A.review_text: i can appreciate that each coffee is brewed upon order, but the smell of burned coffee kind of ruins my experience.  i could even smell it across the street during workouts at burn.  if you want to be seen, this is definitely the scene.  didn't find much hospitality from the workers either.  i'll stick to my philz.

sOMhmdxxRPbolQ2hmFZJqw.review_text: This is a nice place to have a drink in the Mission. The beer selection is pretty good, and if the evening is not chilly it's very nice to enjoy your drink on the outside tables. It was funny when I asked for some  food, the bartender suggested me to go into the next-door Mexican food shop and bring my food inside :)

zhmAsHk1emnIdtTKiHx_Sw.review_text: Searching for that perfect place to plot your overthrow of the corporatocracy? Craving a spot where you can bask in the glorious Mission sunshine while the sweet smell of freshly burned sensimilla wafts by? Got a hankering for some rad live music this Sunday?   Then come on down to one of my favorite Mission spots and get a pint, a cupa, a glass, a bite, a....whatever! Just come on down, and GET DOWN with the Revolucion, baby! Ha. Power to the Peaceful.

XE8Jc_84wybVBP8k1HcmPA.review_text: When judging an establishment I like to look at the pros & cons  PROS:  - outdoor seating  - average to above average jazz music  - coffee, beer, and wine all under the same roof  - everybody wears black  - not full of hipsters  CONS:  - not enough seating (always packed with people)  - uncomfortable chairs (I like butt comfort)  - full of hippies  Anyways, to be honest, I do like this place. It has a really good atmosphere which definitely outweighs any pain I might be in. Plus I can drink wine, smoke a cigarette, and listen to jazz all at the same time.

p1BSvgmuGZuDg3xPnzwUww.review_text: This dark European café takes some stylings cues from a bar you might find in France. It's the kind of place you could hang out morning, noon or  night. It just feels comfortable like an old pair of jeans. They have live music seven days a week. The drinks are good. The atmosphere is perfect. Don't forget to check out Classical music Mondays. They are a local hit.

zdRpRPiXFL4JZGZsgiZLQg.review_text: where the fuck else would i like to be at 10 pm when I do not want to be in a bar? revolution of course.   caffeine? check. alcohol? check. outdoor seating/heaters? check. various wafts of weed, b.o., dog, and ? drifting in? check.  plus I can look at the 4 people inside cava 22 across the street and remind myself how much more fun I am having.

g5g4ol33RXb8wa_L0P_7pg.review_text: I walked into this place feeling like Obe Wan Kenobi in that bar scene from Star Wars. I slowly began to realize the scene was very laid back and chill. Good coffee, good tunes, and very chill people. Not my crowd, but I definitely enjoy picking up coffee coffee from this joint. Cheers! The outside seating is pretty dope too...literally.

cOh7Q7tSBzN1e_U-H6uS3A.review_text: This would be a nice place to have lunch if there was any evidence they cared about service or food.  It shouldn't take 25 minutes to deliver a mediocre grilled cheese sandwich.  The first time I let it pass, but the second time I wanted to go and retreive the 2 bucks I had but into the tip jar.  The staff is sullen and clearly wishes it was doing something else.  My only thought is that they are trying to create a true Soviet style restaurant experience.  SFD

5aaTOIf_wo96-qQSFeNf_w.review_text: Truly the closest I have come to a European experience in the US, even though SF is already cosmopolitan enough. It's not the kind of place the people bury themselves into a computer and not talk to each other. I have met so many people there just sitting down having a coffee or a beer, it's great!

3V2aSUZE49yoykOB0ts5Rg.review_text: First of all , my sandwich was delicious - the ham/brie/pear and it came with salad.  Still you have to be in the mood for the place. Music was very loud and service was slow. And yes, it's filled with those ubiquitous Mission Street hipsters with piercings, attitude, and funny hats. It was too loud to carry on a phone conversation. And staff seemed intent on being ironic and cool. But if you're in the mood, go for it.

duymKKwUruH8GwbvcaFd0w.review_text: I've always loved this spot.  It's got enough reviews already but I just figured I'd add my support.    The best thing from my last visit (aside from the way the evening turned out overall) was that I picked up a piece of charcoal that some artists had inadvertently left after finishing their pieces.  The last time I drew with charcoal was so long ago!

Xjqjybz5YqjJClje_s2ULw.review_text: I'm really digging the multipurpose bar/cafe/restaurant thing right now.  Which makes Cafe du Soleil and Revolution Cafe my new favorite places.  I can bring friends for some coffee talk on a sunny afternoon, get a meal, get work done...the options are many.  Revolution attracts an interesting crowd...yesterday there was a guy reading Kant, three face-painted families (the kids AND the parents rocked the face paint) having some sort of celebration, people working on their laptops (free wifi), and some cute hipster girls.  PLUS there was a girl in a Yelp shirt.  I only got an iced tea, but the food menu looked great so I may stop by closer to lunch- or dinnertime next time.  Kudos to the cute server who was really patient with my friends who couldn't decide what to order (but it was their birthdays, so they're allowed to be as indecisive as they want, I say).  And kudos to the people around us who didn't give us dirty looks even though we were kinda loud (again, pulling the bday excuse).  The bad part about a cafe that opens right onto the street?  I got two mosquito bites.  Though I guess that wasn't necessarily at Revolution...I was out and about a lot yesterday.

ctr_BlCf3Ogny-vLs8E9tQ.review_text: Wednesdays:  Marcus Shelby Trio from 9:00pm to midnight.  Great music.  Good prices on beer and wine, and friendly service.  They have Leffe AND Chimay AND a really nice Côtes-du-Rhone!  I almost gave up on going out to see live music during the work week, but after Marcus let me know about his weekly Wednesday gig, now at least I have "jazz night" at Cafe Rev!

7nUIDRxi7o50agPP3Wo1FA.review_text: I would have given The Revolution Cafe three stars but I added another star for my Virgin Mary sighting. . .but first. . .  . . .it seems like The Revolution Cafe was plucked out of Bourbon Street and dropped in the Mission.  Great dirty French/Indochine/Bayou vibe.  They serve excellent coffee, beers (Chimay and the like), and other groovy items like my favorite:  The Ginger Beer Latte.  That is by far the craziest and most satisfying hot drink I've ever had...ever!  They serve cafe food which looks good.  This place is about chilling with a nice beverage, listening to some good old blues band, and living in the mo.  Great patio atmosphere.    Was here Thursday night and the place was packed.  Cozy, intimate conversations, loud laughing, and one couple hugging and kissing - although it wasn't obnoxious.  Everyone doing their thang.  I don't know, it just works.    So yes, I saw the Virgin Mary Thursday night.    There is a canoe boat thing hanging on the wall.  I was looking up at the wall and all of a suddent a vision of Virgin Mary appeared in the canoe!  I'm not that religious.  What the?!   My friend asks what is going on and I say, "Oh my God, I just saw the Virgin Mary in the canoe on the wall!"  We leave the cafe and stand outside the business next door chatting, and I look up at the wall in the business next to the Revolution Cafe and there is a Virgin Mary alter on the wall opposite the wall in the cafe where I saw the Virgin Mary in the canoe!     The Revolution Cafe - a religious experience!

OTcKsnEQ1Fm0EJ5YsSSgZw.review_text: We stopped at this place before heading next door to Lolo.    The good points:  Revolution has got a vibrant decor, great outdoor seating area and some really good music playing.  Awesome for people watching, taking advantage of the free wifi or just chilling.  And some not so good points:  Revolution also has some extremely abysmal service.  I'm sorry to interrupt your clearly life changing discussion on the "plastification" (yes, this is the word he used) of modern jazz, but could I order a drink? The guy tending the bar shot me this look like I'd just committed some atrocity for even presuming I could order something... wtf?  When I did finally get my drink haphazardly shot my way, a chai latte, it was watery and overly chai (if that makes any sense to you chai drinkers).

6S-WD1XBht_HBSL5_eSR_Q.review_text: This is one of those places that you immediately fall in love with.   They have live local music, wine, beer and side walk seating.   Go on a warm summer night and you'll soon be taken in by its charm.

eSJjyu2CQPk0JsBvIE3mHw.review_text: This little joint has great character.  Came here on a Friday night to find live music and a solid crowd.  Had a couple of beers and great conversations with friends.  Food on the menu looked pretty good and would be worth checking out.  Good first impressions of Revolution Cafe earn it five stars.

sFP8CNt6hFqepeiuqgj6fg.review_text: If this place was bigger, it would be that much more awesome. Live music, good morning coffee, beer in the evening, close to home...its not bad.

nBKwupbsiEWoE_-a5UJMkQ.review_text: I do bike messenger work and frequently have night shifts where it's slow so a good spot to chill on standby is essential.  The Revolution Cafe is that chill spot if I'm in the Mission late at night. It's just a nice casual bar/cafe type deal with a pretty good live band. No pretentious hipsterer-than-thou nonsense here, just a good late-night spot.  Their coffee is pretty good, can't comment on the bar or food side of things beyond their good beer selection at a glance.

IcDn5f-a5mt7v3WnFBvOdg.review_text: Cool, little dirty place. Live music. Quality teas. Good beer selection.

5z2nW6VytwdX3-aEpmTRTQ.review_text: One of my favorite spots in the city.  I accidentally stumbled into this joint one hot summer night. Ever since that first encounter I  can't get enough Revolution.  It's always crowded, loud and hard to find a spot to sit.  But the energy in this place is amazing.    The Expereince: Some sort of quirky band will be playing and you will end up sitting on top of the trombone player becuase, really, it is that crowded!  The patrons will spill out of the cafe onto the sidewalk.  And its not half bad out there, standing, listening to the music and sipping your beer on a warm summer night.

cCeCQxErE9ToaQQBEVFuFA.review_text: things i enjoy about Revolution: its small, but never too crowded great beers on tap outdoor patio next to Escape from NY pizza fun music, live bands.  we've been coming here recently, and glad it's made it to our 'cool mission hangout' spots.

4JAoF46FUBIab5cQsBsuNA.review_text: I change my mind, this place isn't really half bad. Okay, okay, I do admit the sight of cute hipsters in their "unpretentious" Ray Ban Wayferers "changed my mind" about this place. I have a weakness! And it's for hipsters!  Today I went here. I had a cup of iced-coffee. I think the barista lady remembered who I was the first time I went. She was actually smiling to me, and acted friendly! Sure, the service is a bit, okay, a lot slow, but I guess that's what you get when coming to a place where the people think they're too cool for school.

N7sQy7NVzIE2M9VEq0c7og.review_text: a Not So Brief Review of my First Visit to Cafe Revolution:  the live music tonight: A+. two thumbs up.  the staff: civil upon ordering a first drink; friendly upon ordering a second. i completely respect (dare i say, even *endorse*) this approach.  the drinks: bonus points for a semi-obscure austrian wine. yeah!  the physical space: dark, populated, stuff on the walls. yes, those wooden tables are sticky - so what?  the other people: in general, an eclectic mix. the enthusiastic, intoxicated group of guys who tried to chat me up: no skills in that department, but they made for above-average eavesdropping before they tried to include me in their conversation. the strange group of artsy folk who followed them: perfect table-neighbors, no complaints there.   the wretched group of increasingly drunk chicks who had the *other* table next to me, and who kept multiplying like bacteria on a bloody petri dish: dear god, i hope they all finish their nights making offerings to the porcelain deity whilst bowed in deepest supplication. :P gradually spilling over to the point of taking over my table: maybe not the end of the world, but would it have killed them to *ask*? that one blond chick repeatedly flailing into my book while gesturing her way through the world's most vapid conversation (yet failing to notice, even once, that she'd hit something - or that the person holding what she'd hit was glaring at her with progressive intensity): seriously and significantly irksome. the part where the same blond chick *partially sat on me*, knocked my bag over, and never once acknowledged that maybe - just maybe - she was invading someone's goddamn bubble: this would be the point at which i gave up, stopped by the corner store, and came home.  assuming this gaggle of self-absorbed marina-looking specimens was an aberration,  i give this place four stars - though if my next visit finds me fleeing certain phagocytosis by an ameboid mass of narcissistic embodied stereotypes, i may have to reconsider (or "accidentally" crush some pointy-toed feet on my way out the door).

U1fYcbo-hRYKm4gIrVqz2A.review_text: This place is so much fun.  Really friendly bartender, awesome music, great ambiance, and tons of people.  The only time I'm unhappy there is when it's so crowded you can't move.  But if you go late enough it's not as bad.

7NNU7DvCNGenbkGtmMxj5A.review_text: For a small time café this place does just about everything right. I'd say its not a study type of place, but everything else is kickin. They've got tons of beer and drinks including wine and sangria. You can buy the sangria in a pitcher form which is pretty perfect for a bunch of friends. They host music events regularly and for a small place it fits in just right. The alcohol they sell for cheaper on week nights by like 2$ which kicks ass. There's tons of little tables and chairs and benches and couches everywhere and you can group up with a bunch of people and just chat the night away with ease. They have indoor and outdoor seating and there's people going in and out all the time or just hanging round out front chatting. Smokers def dig this place. I'm not sure what's the deal with the name. Kinda not alot connecting it with the atmosphere, but w/e I guess. Every place has got to have some kinda hook in their name I guess. There's a piano against the wall when you come in which they use for performances. I'd be surprised if you couldn't play it regularly though too.  They make food here as well which I didn't get to try, but I have a feeling is prob pretty good. This place almost feels like a really mellow bar when you're there at night which is kinda it's main appeal. You get kinda a smarter less rowdy crowd but all the good drinks and fun friendly atmosphere you could ask for. The bathroom in the back is also pretty clean too. All red walls and a couple locks for the person who is just too paranoid about someone walking in on them. Oh I should mention there's just one bathroom, no guys vs girls here.  It's a cash only place which is the only annoyance for me, but like anyone they keep an ATM next to the bar for easy access. I believe the charge is $2.85. Damn you Mission!

OWW96DEHdM4J2_cnYbmypg.review_text: I went on a sunny weekday afternoon. It is a nice place to chill and enjoy people watching and having a beer with a friend. It's a bit loud, but it has really nice music.   Cash only! Coffee is alright.  Food is good.

yfr7xoIX77mmatXrim9EZg.review_text: Cool place.  Relaxed atmosphere.  I really like the open space (they have glass doors that they slide all the way open so it's basically a bar that opens to the street).  Just an all-around cool vibe.  Live music most nights, people just hanging out (smoking pot often).   My only knock is that the drinks are so overpriced.  Well, at least the wine is - $7.50 for a glass of wine isn't unheard of by any means, but being that the wine they are pouring is one that I know of and have bought a bottle of before for like $9 is just annoying.  So I'd say stick with beer.

WpyycAg0ctp3ER9FbOqQIQ.review_text: I'm sorry, but they don't know how to make a cappuccino. If you ask for one, expect a latte.

MF6Cpfd-NexbRNyaIo_DVw.review_text: great place for hanging out if the weather is nice....and if you find the sitting space...I actually like it on the non crowded days....staff is rude... ....one could say it's almost like a cliche for the those pseudo artsy cafes...I guess I have mixed feelings...I think that if there were more cafes with the outside sitting...I don't think that I would really miss this one...

oxl--iAcvMX2RWSqGZXcfQ.review_text: I guess this place would be ok in the daytime or in the early evening? I've only experienced this on weekend evenings and it has always been super packed. You're basically sitting on top of other people (if you're lucky, you're getting smoke blown in your face as you sit on the patio portion) and it's loud. Drinks for a group of 5 barely fit on the tiny, wobbly tables and service is kinda slow.   Someone forwarded me an invite to see music here...hell no. Where the f do you fit people? The sidewalk? Pass. Maybe it's just better as a coffee shop.

yv60ny6vAK6qDzzsK34Zkw.review_text: There are very few places outside Latin America where I've felt like living in a lost chapter of a Magic Realism novel.  I don't even need my index or thumb to make the count.  The Revolution Cafe is one of those places.  Whether you are sipping on some iceless, fruitless sangria, having a Chimay or drinking cheap beer, there is a thin magic layer that turns anything normal into a dream at The Revolution Café.    It doesn't matter if you sit outside and have to put your drinks on the floor behind you, so "technically" you won't  be drinking on the sidewalk.  It doesn't matter if those by passers click their tongue in despair because there's no seating available (I would say not even standing available), and have to go somewhere else.  It doesn't matter if you get asked for money by a couple of hopeless men, or the melodious jazz duo stops playing for a while and you're still on the mood to snap your fingers.  You'll still breathe in air that feels like crushed planets dust, that smell like leaves, cocktails and wood, and the different aromas coming out of the many bodies lingering at The Revolution Café.  I wish I'd had a place like this closer.  It would be part of my life.  There is nothing as feeling like you were made by lines of character development and exquisite plots.  Here, I was the "girl visiting from Seattle" but still a regular shook my hand, and asked me for Kurt Cobain and the incessant rain, while checking if my left elbow was working well.  Only in Mission.  I'm bringing back to Seattle my own ISBN number, courtesy of The Revolution Café.  ¡Gracias!

OJtzn6zWNYx7LzvLEGOFyQ.review_text: They have really great Sangria!   Cute little place with a the ambiance you'd expect from a place called "revolution cafe." Well priced Sangria, little old-school wooden tables and overall a place I enjoy coming too for a drink (and they have coffee too).

XYDyktd9zsqPvJxxSTDxNw.review_text: 5pm Wednesday for Happy Hour.  Cute little place on the corner.  However, they didn't have any sangria, ginger beer, or olives, which ironically was our entire initial order. Kinda rough start to the happy hour.  Guess we'll have to choose more carefully next time.

20zmSG3PS7-bor5q2JCsMw.review_text: As I walked in this joint, I asked the bartender if it was happy hour.  His reply? "It's always happy here" , in a French accent.  that got me to buy a piece of pie.    Great corner location off a side street, so you get to people watch without all the traffic of Mission or Valencia, and the full non-alcoholic menu allows non-lushes like myself to hang.

1W4c1ZOr7B4jixG3lLp6Qg.review_text: there is never a time when i go to the rev, that im disappointed....  i always find myself talking with strangers, random conversations, sipping on cerveza (lagunitas), enjoying the heat lamps during those cold cold nights in sf, listening to live music all with a diverse and humble crowd, just my kind of scene!  then if i feel hungry (which usually happens after a few lagunitas) i order a slice of pizza at one of my favorites, only one block away,  where they make a fresh slice just for you and me and the whole wide world, ull find no pizza sitting under the heat lamp waiting to be eaten there,,,serranos pizza , ur simply the best...tun tun tun tun...better than all the rest....

8pONVRF4HDD9ynt5lCynTQ.review_text: The Revolution Cafe is good for a lot of things: QUIET contemplation, a QUIET cup of coffee, QUIETLY planning a revolution, QUIETLY enjoying the sunshine during daylight hours, drinking sangria with a few friends and QUIETLY chatting amongst yourselves. You get it. It should be called The Library Cafe or Enjoy The Silence Cafe.    The Revolution Cafe is absolutely NOT good for one thing. And that one thing is a pack of drunk post-brunch Yelpers, rolling 15 deep, on a QUIET, sunny Saturday afternoon. Who are these people at The Revolution Cafe? How is it they appear to be both sober AND well-rested at 2 p.m. on a Saturday? Why are they glaring at us and why is steam coming out of their ears?  OK! My Bad! I had only been to The Revolution Cafe for live music at night before and I was probably already drunk everytime I showed up there. I also remembered them having some killer sangria and being a lot cheaper than Medjool. I wouldn't know now. Our plans came to a screeching halt once we set foot in TRC and realized that 15 of these things were not like the others. Something about "Revolution" makes me think loud and rowdy. I couldn't have been more wrong. So like any good mother hen, I rounded up my naughty chicks, took a head count, and herded them back to Medjool. Where our kind is always welcomed with full Stellas and a hefty bar bill.   The Revolution Cafe has lots of outdoor seating, beers on tap, a wine selection, and great sangria. Someday when I get my act together and learn how to read, I'll QUIETLY sit outside, sip my coffee, and read the paper. Until then, you can find me on the roof at Medjool, slumped over a chair, yelling about something or other.

dtIDlch0539EkWfx9utgOw.review_text: Awesome. I just seem to have a great time here no matter who I'm with. It takes a special place to do that.  They have great music too. Awesome bluegrass and jazz at night.

JhRRBFvqpEmWUXrjHjRuUA.review_text: 1 Star because the atmosphere is cool.  Otherwise I'd give it none.  Bad service, dirty and crummy bagels = 1 star.

bdZLmvZg7ibzD0YbLfru6A.review_text: Came here on a late Saturday night to keep awake.  Thus, we grabbed a couple orders of coffee.  Unfortunately they had barely enough left.  So, the guy pours us the rest of the coffee they had left for three cups and only charges us for one cup instead, since he felt bad for not having any more coffee.  It's all good, I believe we tipped to compensate for the initial charge.  The coffee itself was pretty darn strong, and we managed to find an outdoor spot outside to sip our darn strong coffee.  I can easily say that we were very wide awake for the ride home. :)

0ixUVjnxiD0cV-lPn39Ltw.review_text: ONe of the Hippest places in S.F. something for everyone!

tmxwP7MRZ99pYbc-jDSXBA.review_text: Great place, even if I rarely went here.

AHz3sGxkZjAzv8uu0Q9hqg.review_text: Deja vu.  I feel like I've been here before, but I don't know how or when.  I can't believe that I found this place with co-workers on a random night out.   We ended up drinking some beer and people watching.  Yes, the place is full of interesting local characters.  The key word in the name of this establishment is "REVOLUTION".  This place is hip, young...but is totally not the same stuffy bar or cafe that you see in other parts of the city.  It is revolutionary in many ways.  It goes against the expectations of the "normal" after-work watering hole.   It is drastically different.   Plus, gotta love the uhmm..."SAN FRANCISCAN" atmosphere..uhmm...if you know what I mean.

oko4L9QZA_jwCW3hBkNBEQ.review_text: Being the 200 and 1st fan of this place, I guess that it goes without saying that it's pretty awesome. I finally went in this past week, and it just so happen to be live music night! It's a great place to go when it's warm out because of its indoor/outdoor layout, and to enjoy a quick bit to eat and a drink. The prices are really reasonable (especially for a big yummy hot chocolate), and they have free wifi if you ever want to nerd out!

qBN5KgoZIyPRiC34IV5qTg.review_text: Horrible service.  My friends and I went for lunch at 2pm and though only 3 people were in the cafe, we couldn't find anyone to help us at the counter for 5 minutes.  When the guy finally showed up, he took 1 sandwich order at a time, never said a word to us, and then took 20 minutes to make 3 sandwiches.  He had packed them to go and threw some change at us telling us we weren't welcome because we didn't tip him enough...I'm glad we didn't...and he was too much of an idiot to realize he threw more money at us than we had tipped him to begin with.  We left the sandwiches and went somewhere else.  On the way back, we saw the sandwiches still sitting at the table...he was too lazy to clean up the table during that entire hour.

Z-x2yNZL6pz5OW4hlTaYbg.review_text: Nice place with great live music ,friendly service, will be back !

Nf8FGQb7ocrlNvU_S5Y_cg.review_text: The coffee and the food is fine. The reason to go is the atmosphere - open patio and handsome architecture. This is the perfect place to spend a day, starting with some coffee and free wifi in the afternoon and sliding into a beer and music in the early evening.  Just fyi, it's a madhouse on weekend nights - stick to daytime and weeknights.

GfVPzuscQLOUk8wDkUOLOg.review_text: For what this place is, it is a ten!  The best and most interesting mix of patrons ever (possibly with the exception of 540 Club).  One guy sat down and played the piano during my second visit.  A friendly service staff, and Chimay on tap.  I love it for mid to late afternoon visits when you want to chill, and have been twice during that time.  I am not sure how it is at night but we have walked by on our pub crawls and it is always hopping.

pSO39IoF-RVHgkuoC3taAw.review_text: The people who work here are jerks.

Cfo08zrATMf9m9Qh1UtcXA.review_text: always enjoying to be here. always open to interesting conversations, great little get social spot.  sangrias are good too..

55vt2DCD6Btq4wRbjMk41g.review_text: My friend had office hours at revolution when he flew through town a few weeks ago. The free wifi, tables you can pull together and the sunny afternoon made for a perfect meet-up. They serve coffee and beer as well with both fat tire, chimay on tap. They do serve food and they also allow dogs. Crowd is hipstery and relaxed. Bartenders were fabulous. They also serve food.

fW971v8bt2_dzbiUCZ_7UQ.review_text: It's going to be awhile before I give this place another shot.    I WAS enjoying a delicious breakfast when the person working the counter started spraying insect spray at the flies hovering over the pastries.  While she had the foresight to cover the pastries before doing this, the spray was still going everywhere else including the clean glasses and servingware, and probably my lungs.  (Which, granted, have probably seen worse toxins).   The pancakes were fucking DELICIOUS however.

lY5l8PUFBeZ7Dhd9ccFekA.review_text: I feel like I am being stingy with my star rating on this one, a place that generally seems to be a crowd pleaser, and which I too like when in a frame of mind, but for the uses that I seek out Mission cafes it leaves a bit to be desired. Typically between the hours of 10 a.m. and 1 p.m. I am looking for a comfortable place to read and write (by printed page and by hand), and Revolution Café is simply too dark unless a seat can be found almost on the sidewalk with the drawback that stinky cigarette smoke wafts over this section. Smoking, at one time allowed in this section, has since been banned but the smokers---and this café seems to attract an inordinate number--have moved two feet away to the trash bin, still breathing their foulness within.  Occasionally, of an afternoon, somebody will commandeer the piano and tickle out a few tunes, lending an atmosphere of casual bohemianism that was once more widespread in the neighborhood but is increasingly rare, and for this Revolution Café is much appreciated. Also, I have once or twice stopped briefly by in an evening and enjoyed the space as an entertainment, for which use it is recommendable.

8CbzVfLZqpZkQJ7as1zDFA.review_text: i wanted to go here for years and finally did one Thursday afternoon. I would call it a "dive" coffee shop and I loved it! Great people watching, nothing pretentious, funky, and just the kind of spot I would want to hang out at all the time, if only I lived closer.   They have coffee/tea/beer/wine what every is your feeling. My tea and bagel were good and the service was awesome with a smile! BTW - The smoke from outside tables did drift inside so that may bother some.

psh81651yroUHLu8xFHz2A.review_text: Of course my Anarchist friend LOVES this place.  I, on the other hand,  don't really see what the big deal is.  Although the decor may be quite comfortable and nice, there's never anywhere to sit and it's cramped.  And to the guy there to read your Marxist/Leninist/Post-Modern whatever book: How the hell are you reading in this place?!  It's loud and crazy in here!  You're a big fat faker.  There's a few beers on tap.  Some sangria.  A little pot smoking...actually...a lot of pot smoking.  One time the barista gave me the last of his joint.  Viva la Revolucion!  Some hippies playing jazz.  The sandwiches look fancy but are just okay.  Get there early before all the seats are taken is all I'm sayin'...comrade.

Zqu-tMR9CHjA44sU7I5bXA.review_text: An outdoor cafe in SF where I DON'T feel cold? Stumbling upon GOOD live jazz on a Tuesday night? A variety of drinks including tea, beer AND wine? European-esque atmosphere reminiscent of my European FANTASIES? Why isn't this in MY neighborhood? Why didn't I know about this place when I LIVED IN THE MISSION?  Oh god, I am in LOVE.

VhSPwaK7B15S9NhFkcT4Xg.review_text: impossibly divine. (1 star)  Update:  Of course Revolution deserves 5 stars, but act like you didn't see it, ok?  Go see the live classical on Sundays, if it's still going.  Say hi to the guys playing for me, and the bartender.  God, I miss the city.

zKmHf9hhsxqZuwQvSMx4dQ.review_text: Not my usual type of place, but went on a Monday night with a friend and was stoked with the Mini orchestra playing inside;0) Joe at the bar was a gem and I loved the mellow vibe.

GfB6sC4NJQvSI2ewbQrDNA.review_text: Really cool chill place.  I came in here after work and had a salad and some beer. I had the Cesar salad with chicken.  The chicken was edible but tasted like it was sitting around for a real long time, very dry.  They have Leffe and Chimay on tap, my favorites!  The band was a real cool jazz band with a piano, alto sax, acoustic bass and drummer.  Sounded really good in the place since half of the front is open.  They have heat lamps which surprisingly keeps it pretty warm.  They have bands here it seems every night which really gives the place an amazing atmosphere.  They were also playing Bob Dylan and the Band songs which was cool.  I haven't had their Sangria but I want to try it.  I'm just havin some beer tonight.  I'm lucky that it's actually on my way home from work now.  I just wish that the food was better. update: I saw a Klezmer band here 2 weeks ago and it was awesome!  Such a cool vibe and the crowd flowed right out onto the street.  Nothing like any place I know of in SF.  Bumping to 5 stars.

WecuAsHBDZGj7Z6_sJcQAw.review_text: Start a (sandwich) revolution.  More sandwiches need baked tofu.  More sandwiches need hummus (which they'll add no charge if you ask).  More sandwiches need to be toasted.  More sandwiches need to come with a side of greens.  More cafes need open doors and let the fresh air in, serve beer and wine, offer free (if spotty) WiFi and welcome such an eclectic gathering of the Mission's finest.  Even the folk/country music sounded good.  More places need to be like Revolution Cafe.

R4DVayqiW63jHle7AG_NXQ.review_text: I don't know what to say about  this place, I just don't. I wish I could like it, but... eh. small place that gets packed pretty quickly. Every time I've been there, there have been some crazy movies being shown of all this weird stuff, or some really WEIRD music being played. Crowd is friendly enough, but if you sit outside, almost all everyone wants to do is smoke pot. I am not into that at all, so I don't really care to sit on the outside. Drinks are moderately priced, but it really is more of a cafe than a bar, so don't expect a lot. You have the option of whatever is on the menu and that's it. Crowds are MASSIVE almost every night. There is only one unisex bathroom. Okay place overall, but I just am not really into the type of crowd that this place attracts.

jpx0mV-7tl6OMBNDFoH4Mw.review_text: One man's experience on an early Friday evening during a recent (May '08) heatwave: The anti-Ritual.  Welcoming, convivial, and open.  Inclusive of all races, ages, and orientations.  No immature hipster pretensions or foolishness.  Warm smiles and people in sync, general politeness: "please", "thank you", "excuse me".  Nice service.  Sweet, not-so-mysterious scents in the air.  Prime San Francisco.  Ah, Cafe Revolucion...

_7Xr_D_JP-hvIo4g8A6J5Q.review_text: This is seriously my favorite cafe in San Francisco. The atmosphere is awesome and i love their interior decor. Not to mention that their coffee is delicious, and i'm pretty picky with my coffee. The best part? They have live music! I'm seriously going back here every chance i get!

aN3bpfDLsMjQloJ_4-P13Q.review_text: I bet I'd be giving this place five stars right now if I was a caffeine addict & still smoked. My brief eyeing of the hot beverages menu (with Yelp in mind) revealed the usual coffee drink varieties ranging in price from $1 for a plain cup of to $3 for a latte. You can sit and smoke and drink on the sundrenched front patio if you're lucky enough to snag a seat (full at 2:30pm on a Monday).   Being as I'm an alcoholic instead of a caffeine addict, this cafe only gets three stars, as every adult beverage on the menu should have been at least $1 cheaper & the bathroom stank.   From the other reviews, it sounds like this is a spot to check out more in the evening for live music and the like. The daytime scene - cool art on the walls & middle aged men taking advantage of the free wi-fi (or making their attempts at the great american novel, who knows).   Foodwise, they offer sandwiches and salads. None of which sounded terribly special.

dAzvgrwL-2r7TYSSAuID5A.review_text: It's a nice bar ala Paris cafe, with good wine and beer options. The food is ok, not anything special. A friend of mine used to work here and I'd always come by to hang out (and get pretty blitzed in the process). A place you can drink  and smoke outside is pretty alright in my book. I haven't been back in about a 1 or so, but it's a sweet bar to check out the nightlife around the Mission. They have free bands and musicians there sometimes which helps with the ambiance.

Um0Mp2Vn1tYS1TFnsvOWpA.review_text: No, no, no.  I'm tired of your rejection, RevCafe.  You teased me with breakfast bagels -- half the time, you have no bagels.  You made me want nothing more on a hot Mission day than to sit in the breeze with a salad -- oh, I'm sorry, you don't have any salad greens today?  Does not half of your menu involve salad?  Fine, a grilled cheese?  30 minutes later, I'm still sitting at my cute artsy table surrounded by cute artsy pot smokers and I am starving in neither a cute nor artsy way.  Suggestion: just stop pretending you have a menu you are barely capable of serving.  We all lower our expectations of hipsters, yes -- but a line must be drawn.  That line is called soy milk.

DG-e1J073nzSYS1NsfxoMQ.review_text: This is one of those places you stumble upon while walking through a nieghborhood you don't really know and its like a little european cafe in a latin hood.  The space is great and many of the patrons seem to be solving the words problems, writing a novel, or just trying like a son a bitch to look cool in a i am so not trying to look cool way.  (i love the mission its the all the uberhipsters i can do without) Any way aside from the posers and a pretty shitty pastery selection this is a great place that has real sf vibe.  PS they often have a live music and decent offering of sanwiches and salads.

L-TX5J5eWj495p4JvI-2QA.review_text: Went there with the kiddo to see the classical string jam last night.  No music start for a half hour after the announced 8pm.  Then it was kind of a modal fusion thing - guitar and violin - meh.  We were expecting a classical quartet - maybe some chamber music.  Any how there was no seating - the place is tiny.  And there is a lot of weed and cigarettes smoked just outside where there are tables and chairs (all occupied) but where we hoped to listen a bit.  The smoked bothered the eyes and lungs of the 14 year old.  Fortunately there was a pizza place next door where we could get a decent slice. There are much better coffee house venues for music on the peninsula.  You might like this place if Bohemian, young and 420 friendly is your thing.  Clearly lots of people like the place - just not for families hoping to expose their kids to classical music.  Amending up - thoughtful reply from the owner.  And kudos for innovation of hosting the classical jams generally.

EVwkwbMqLDRZuY7yGWgKxw.review_text: Awesome.  They just got their beer/wine back after a brief suspension for people drinking on the sidewalk.  As long as everyone plays nice this will remain the best place in the mission to hang out and work, study, drink, and listen to frequent live music.

R34DFfynBionQhDsdlf4Sg.review_text: i must say, this is now possibly my favorite spot in the mission for sipping and people watching and listening to whatever musicians may be playing.  on a sunny day/evening you will be hard pressed to find a seat, but if you do you must swoop down upon it like a fierce, fierce eagle, for if you don't i will slide in there and sit down a millisecond before you, and say, "oh, im so sorry, were you going to sit here???" and then ill ignore you and start yelping on my laptop about how slow the people are at papa toby's revolution cafe.  im just kidding, i would never do that.  especially if you are at the cafe, because in my experience, the clientile is very kind and nice and undeserving of such immature behavior.  with the glass-door store-front opened up on nice days, it is really a pleasure to sit and do whatever you must do at the revolution cafe.

O25h1oPLt4gRANU5-pPJEw.review_text: I simply love this place.  you can seat here everyday enjoy the lazy afternoon or sexy evening. eclectic crowd, nice friendly service, good selection of drinks, good vibes, great ambient, (amazing chocolate scones  too!)  and now - something unbeatable: great music choices. great background music.

K9ejqgRQsGQOuM43hKtN8Q.review_text: Chillest spot in the Mission, Hands down. Live music, beautiful, attentive bartenders, mellow, worldly crowd (last time i went there must have been 5 different groups speaking as many different languages), generous vibrations, super sweet art, nice lighting, great food, and cool outdoor chillin' area, perfect for shmokin' anything you wish.  Overall, wonderful atmosphere and BART-able location. I dunno if it incites any revolution, but I think it lives up to its name based on the community that it creates, alone.

72KqFyXMH4FNvrgkf1DCxw.review_text: The noise to personal space ratio was way too high, the bartender/waitress was unfriendly, they didn't have any desserts (you're a cafe - sell some cookies), and the place smelled like cigarettes and pot.  It's the sort of place people go to feel cool in an "alternative" sort of a way; the hippie chick sitting at the table next to mine seemed delighted that her yuppie boyfriend brought her there.  Live music is always nice and the creepy hunchbacked hobo was amusing, but there's nothing "cozy" about this place.  I'm never going to subject myself to that again, but I suppose if you work in the Financial District and have a crush on a dirty girl, taking her here might get you laid.

WtDdZoi5HDxFUb3vvbk_1w.review_text: ok, they don't have good coffee drinks. But location and atmopshere is cool. You can always find mission hipters hanging out there....open until late. I recommend just ordering sangria instead of coffee drinks.

2bFSM7AZbdquRchcEuyCwA.review_text: My friend Steve is the kind of guy who shows up in the S.F. Bay Area like a month ago and already knows about more cool places than I do. Case in point: Revolution Cafe. I had no idea this little gem was hiding in plain sight, within walking distance of my house no less.   Well, that's a lie. I had some idea, because I'd walked past it a few times and it was always packed with what looked like a vaguely pretentious European crowd, and I was always on my way to another bar in the area so I never sat down. But once I did, I tapped into my inner pretentious Euro and blended right in. Sidewalk tables, red wine, and free live music. Viva la Revolution.

6dR7ISfQ7f7wR9vmaKAWmw.review_text: p.s.    I live about a block away from this place and have visited many many times. I have many "first hand experiences". So don't flag me for not having first hand experiences. This place is like groundhog day, always the same. If the YELP moderators don't like my review they should go visit the cafe themselves.

44wUH2oABBkCd7wu_O4VHw.review_text: Oooh I love this place and it's atmosphere, and the mood I was in while sittin there sippin. I've been meaning to come by by night for some live music and wine but ended up coming on a foggy weekday noonish with a friend for some coffee and chats. Witnessed the sun come out before me and enjoyed an ice coffee and chai latte (though I've definitely had chais) but it was mostly for the atmosphere and though perhaps I felt a little out of place among the immediate locals (mostly men) who just sat there hanging out smoking cigarettes drinking going on laptops eating etc and seemed to know almost everybody who walked by, I enjoyed it oh so and cannot wait to return by night for some music. Oh, also the daytime music they played contributed to the vibe and had me slowdancing in my seat. Oh San Francisco!

iEX-Zdndctva8cj2SJrIAg.review_text: One of my favorite neighborhood coffee spots (and favorite places to go to "work" with my laptop during the day). Free wifi, and you can linger as long as you want. Generally uncrowded during the weekdays. The food isn't anything special, but the atmosphere is mellow and cool -- very Parisian sidewalk cafe.

1x4jgOGTgChLcXasPfe9zw.review_text: i am in love with this place.  i only discovered it last weekend when i stopped in for a drink (or two. or three. ?  ::bites lip::  i can't remember.) after work but i have come back once already and i hope to go back again before i leave the bay area (which, unfortunately, will be in one short week).    they have music pretty much every night (i hesitate to say EVERY night because i don't have confirmation on it.. but i'm pretty sure it's close to every night) which always includes good and talented musicians.  the music also varies each night and by time of day.  for instance, when i arrived at 8:30 on sunday night a jazz group was just finishing up and later a group of improv classical players came together and played (including pianists, violinists, etc).   music playlists heard during the day when live music isn't around also include all types of sounds from around the world, which was very refreshing.  i love that this place serves coffee, beer, alcohol, sandwiches and appetizers.  they also have free wireless and a happy hour from 3-6.  this means you can go there at any time of the day and be happy.  from breakfast coffee shop to daytime laptop/snack stop to nighttime bar/hangout.    i can't speak for the food itself since i haven't eaten here.. but it looks good when i see at the table next to me.  the atmosphere is awesome in that they have both indoor and outdoor seating.  space heaters are available for when the weather gets chilly.  also, there is a great mix of people in here at various hours of the day.  excellent people watching too!  thumbs up to revolution!

kMYBGRBSMLkkoUYeNUhcNQ.review_text: love this place, it transports me somewhere abroad every time.

xWiirESH97dE6U0oT1MSKQ.review_text: I'm not quite sure how i feel about the revolution cafe.  as far as ordering, the signage is hard to read and i wasn't getting good vibes from the waitress who was waiting for me to finish reading to take my order.  also, the don't take plastic.  wtf?  i ordered water and the hot veggie sandwich and listened to some random guy play very loud and dramatic music on the piano as i waited for my food.  the waitress didn't seem particularly pleased with this guy and surveyed several people asking if it was too loud, hoping that someone would eventually tell her what she wanted to hear.  food showed up not too long after.  salad and dressing was really good.  sandwich was good as well, thought it was too dense to finish.  overall, it just seemed too loud and crowded (i was inches away from the next table).  decent food but nothing to write home about.

iL-5xEeaQWpESDgKdl-Krw.review_text: I recently lost about 50 VIPs (Very Important Papers) at Revolution Cafe probably due to being distracted by neighborly chatting, switching chairs, untangling laptop chords, eating and just generally being revolutionary. Thus, it is unlikely that I will return to Rev Cafe for "work" anymore and will probably just be going there for crossword puzzles, beers in the afternoon, and to pet dogs. Oh and I still want to check out some music there.  One big warning: Rev Cafe seems to be sorely understaffed at most times during the day and although the food is surprisingly good, during my last outing I waited 30 (thirty) minutes for my sandwich.

8ExCZVowOo3LK2QG6G8Xmg.review_text: Came here with a friend to grab an iced coffee as we waited for dinner nearby. Overall, the shop is okay. Feels a bit dirty (i.e., coffee-rings-on-the-tabletops dirty). Like the fact that bands play here and the option of outdoor seating. Coffee was pretty good and inexpensive. Cash only.

nUJrda97iNO1biQ7XipZGA.review_text: I didn't see anything super cool about it but the crowd was alright, the music was alright but when we went out to it Saturday night, it was just really crowded. It's a small space and it's always crowded.    I didn't like the mocha there, it was really sweet. My boyfriend likes it though.

MuoI1HataJ1eFocaKAROhA.review_text: The atmostphere is perfect -- warm and inviting decor, open-air tables, amazingly great live music (I've never seen a bad act here), and people dancing and having an all-around great time.     I would give it five stars if it were a little less crowded and the tables were cleaner.   I have a feeling there are plenty of people who come for the music, but don't end up buying anything from the cafe at all because it's too much of a challenge to force your way through the crowd to get a drink.

qUYxPCyf-Ofu0CybktNopw.review_text: Sangria a plenty and tamales that were full of veggies and not too much cheese and lovely green salad that covered about all of my needed bases. Plus, the music was beautiful and made me take slower bites to stay longer to hear the lovely songs.

ed9_B3BzUm3pIdepOMnM4A.review_text: Revolution has very quickly become one of my favorite finds in SF. A great place not only to grab some coffee and get some work done, but also to enjoy some evening jazz over beer/wine. As others have mentioned, it feels like a bit of an escape from the rest of the city. I just wish I lived closer!

l0I8QAnHJoLhEozrFilONg.review_text: Are foccacia sandwiches and jazz improv going to be part of the revolution? Probably not, though Chimay could play a role, and fortunately, it's served here.   Having changed owners recently (the Emmy's Spaghetti/Blue Jay people I hear), the Revolution has greatly improved over its earlier incarnation. Whereas the old had a rep for booking lots of boring farty MOR singer-songwriters, jazzy stuff predominates now and is way better. Their food of old was no treat either, and is vastly improved, though culling other reviews here will show that you can still wait forever for it to come and your server may find you a dire pest, probably based solely on how their day has been going.  Where they haven't raised the bar is in their coffee cups. A bit of an improvement as the coffee here used to frequently be apalling and is now upgraded to Bog Standard.  Where the magic happens here is when the weather is nice, the music doesn't suck, you can find a table and the old hippie is bugging somebody else, because you can drink your beer or sangria in the out-of-doors. So when the revolution begins in earnest, let them know us by our Adidas flip-flops!

GTyErdrLIJZF_vGkrlUvgA.review_text: This is the kind of place where every shadowy corner is occupied by a subversive with anachronistic facial hair, scrawling in a tattered notebook as if the revolution depended on it.  This is also the kind of place where if you are two people occupying a table large enough for four, it will be no more than a few minutes before a couple of nomadic-looking folks slide in next to you, light up a joint, and plunge into an intense conversation about Icelandic film.  If you are looking to have an earnest philosophical discussion over a sticky table, read Chomsky while drinking cheap beer, or give your cute-but-square new Marina boyfriend an object lesson on why things would never really work out between you, I can think of no better place.

eo0Eab67OD3oqcitIpX3HQ.review_text: Cool spot  live rap music last night was good, everyone was having a good time! wish they were serving cocktails but wine/beer did the trick...best thing was no pretentious yuppies but only what seems to be a mix of cool cats from SF!

zN2oy9KnIC7JNtTRmYKesA.review_text: Inevitably I find myself here time and time again. Great music and intimate space with good food and good drink. Check out classical rev on monday nights.

WaQ7KcZd3wVozXiDFWIDVA.review_text: The grilled cheese sandwich and tomato soup are great!  And inexpensive.  The music is lovely.  My friend and i sat at an outdoor table, and there were all sorts of tattooed people smoking and shouting next to us.  I suppose this is the essence of Mission District, but I am a yuppie, so that was off-putting.

voO3JlLaERhQiWqBDWvOTg.review_text: So lets pretend you have been up for over twenty-four hours, and it just so happened that last night was NYE and some guy was at a party with little sour teddy bears that were so delicious.  Now lets also assume that you and your girlfriend are total winners in oh-8 so you went to breakfast of champions at 7 am.  Now lets pretend you just called out of work form your dreary corporate coffeeshop job and you were still 'awake'  and hungry and you found yourself doing laps around the mission looking for a friend of a friend's cool condo.  let's say your lost.   your options are wait in line at some uber-trendy eatery down the street (were apparently waiting in line is part of the experience,) or you can sit down and order a veggie melt and calistoga (they didn't have tonic for the tanqueray) ...which would you do? Well you can guess whhich one I chose and I have to say it was great.  The veggie melt has just enough veggie to make you feel like you got your monies worth and not too much melt so felt like you might still be eating something semi-healthy.  The crowd was ultra chill.   The gin and tonics could have been better had they served tonic :P  I will definitely go here again, especially now that I know where it is.  You should too.

MWuPitr2L7gDUhqRB4i4IA.review_text: THIS PLACE IS AWESOME!  My bestie was visiting from Dublin this last weekend and after convincing, we were going to meet friends at the Makeout Room.  We walked into the MOR and they were playing music I just wasn't drunk enough for, so we decided to tell our friends to meet us at Blondies.  On our walk up to Valencia we heard some open mic hiphop.  Since both of us are originally from Sacramento, we were immediately drawn in.  We walked into the packed room, immediately found seating (good seating karma) and I stepped up to the counter, where they happened to have my favorite beer (Radeberger).  I paid for my two beers and we sat and enjoyed a couple of songs before our friends started blowing us up because we had stayed too long!    I will DEFINITELY be coming back to this lil' gem!  :)

kUJEFNOA4w-iSyAe7IeDZA.review_text:
Now my favorite place to spend a weekday evening after work.
  So, what is the revolution?  Apparently, it involves small, easily-rearrangeable tables; the availability but non-dominance of wifi access; and well-heated outdoor spaces to unwittingly include sidewalk passers-by in the cafe context.
  The sangria is excellent, and lately it's been selling out by midnight.  Lots of good alternatives -- the jamaican ginger tea is so frothy it feels like drinking a latte -- but to me the sangria is the star.
  Sept 24th Update: no more longer coconut chai!  well, it was probably sour anyway.

iYeOigbzvpgtCfr_wbOawQ.review_text: Yesterday (13Jan09) someone lit up a joint at a sidewalk table. Four peeps kicked it on back.   I had a Lemon Lover or something like that, blue alcohol swishing around in Lemonade. I kicked it on back.  A perfect place to laze away a sunny day, WIFI access and reading allowed. This place is a mix between a bar with nice, simple but tasty food (think sandwiches and salads) and a coffee shop. The audience is varied and doesn't fit just the MClub card holders mentioned above, but everyone is tolerant of them.   I have also been here on a weeknight and the sangria was tasty but not strong. My sandwich was big and yummy. Seating can be a bit tight, but you just have to ask to share.   I love this spot, it feels cozy and accessible. Hey, don't bogart that J....

QofHOTxS9QwXoTGbz0l0Iw.review_text: Good coffee, great beer, eclectic crowd.  It always has a great vibe and a joint being passed around the front patio.  It kind of feels like Amsterdam.

3rwMNZjKxYGjXrN3yTG-8A.review_text: Finally! a cafe with a liberal political agenda!

JF-7fBtuA_l5R650Iqe7RQ.review_text: i dont know why the bay area doesnt have more places with patios so this place gets 3 stars just for havinga patio. it can be extremely crowded here when there is live music and its not a place where you can easily find a place to stand without standing right in front of someone. i was there on a saturday most recently and the crowd was definitely NOT bohemian by any means. perhaps more enjoyable during the week when it is not overrun by wealthier clientele ifyouknow what i mean.  i like the atmosphere of the place and the staff seemed ok to me. having only one bathroom when you are drinking lots of beers kinda sucks though. more patios, california!! chicago has more patios than the bay area and chicago only has 4 months of decent weather a year, c'mon!!! service is a bit slow but the ham and cheese sandwich is yummy!

RWMnG-9C-mZq76Xg5t9big.review_text: Ive been here a few times and loved it each time. Live music, great photography, great atmosphere friendly and real service and friendly punters. Cant knock it and to top that there has been great live music each time Ive been!! Classical revolution are one to watch. Organised by a chap called Chairn (sorry If a spelt that wrong) he's a great bloke and well worth an chat and listen. I will be back.

Q2Iest8oggBub6nVBFEcNw.review_text: I'm surprised at the low average for this place.  I used this as the rendezvous/staging area for my birthday pub crawl, and it worked brilliantly.  We all gathered around a table outside, eating delicious sandwiches and/or drinking Chimay while listening to the live music and waiting for the rest of our crew to show up.  Plus, it's always lively.  True, sandwiches did take a while (seems like the guy at the counter was stoned), but no big.  Though we did leave once the band with a sousaphone started playing.  Long story short, Papa Toby's is a unique asset in the Mission that you'd do well to take advantage of.

CDZWiihsmtiP-cgBRSSljA.review_text: Would be 3 stars because I vote it Most Likely Place to Spill Sangria on a MacBook (who has a MacBook at a bar on Friday night at 9pm??) When Someone Knocks Your Handbag.  Don't ask me why I nominate it (ok, ask me) but the elbow room here is even less than the Elbo Room.  And the corner of the bar by the bathroom is a clusterf-heeyyyy!  4 stars because the sweet bartender (who had a cool hat on) comped us one drink when we bought two to replace the spilled one.  Otherwise, fine place to stop in for a beer and see and be seen on Friday.  I'll be damned if I'm going to come in, pay for a sangria, and leave.  We finished our own drinks in (our) shame.  But really . . . MacBooks and sangria and weekend nights do not mix.

AnpIbinfzqdoETYZ9XqQ3g.review_text: i needed a spot to park my rear for an hour before i meet up with friends for dinner.  a coworker (thanks iris!) suggested this gem.  i love this little open space cafe blaring jazz.  i ordered a ginger beer and man did it pack a kick.  a good spicy kick that warmed my throat.  i really loved the feel of the place.  reminded me of a lot of the cafes in europe that i have encountered in my travels.  there was even a little french bulldog scampering around.  tres chic!

Gs2bdWy4SNRi6SYQuoQ0Dw.review_text: I heart you more and more!

cFQDeYUQXXx2iUfyOvO6ig.review_text: completely open front of the cafe, tons of seating, a good variety of beers on tap, frequent live music, and fantastic hummus, all reasonably priced- i couldn't ask for much more from a coffee place.  Probably more of a social place than a study place, however, because the energy level is so high.  we were also asked to be quiet by an older woman when we were talking during some live music, but we were outside, the place was packed, and everyone was talking....so I guess this isn't a fault of the place, just don't be offended if it happens to you too.

KBNceewFFeTK-vnv6Y-s7Q.review_text: This place reminds me of an Expat bar in Asia and/or South America.  People are relaxed, chill, and hanging out, it's like they're on vacation, someone's journaling, and folks are drinking and eating.      When it's a nice sun shiny day in the city this place is packed!   Sangria overflows, icy cold beer is dripping with dew in the heat, music playing, and there is a lot of chatter going on.  People spill over onto the sidewalk, squeeze into tight little huddles, no one is bothered by the smoke wafting through the air, people stand, lean, hover as they hook up with friends.  It has a nice chill vibe to it, with lots of flavor.    The only thing that reminds me that it's not an Expat bar and I'm in SF, is the ubiquitous Timbuktu bag on some of the patrons (yeah I got one too!).

sOhv5LHFsyf8t1JpgnocMQ.review_text: This is a nice place to visit to listen to live jazz and drink coffee on 22nd in the Mission. You might find a place like this in North Beach. I had a hot chocolate and enjoyed the jazz band. I'd come back again to hang out, but it is small and a little cramped.

rVkYtaUhx3ZdXgbMdICCwg.review_text: Great little place! Wide selection, AMAZING live jazz on Tuesdays!

uVLbtT7PskoRoHuoOIqECA.review_text: One of my favorite day time mission hang outs- great live music and general atmosphere. Nice to have a chimay and people watch. My man and I are huge fans! Mmm im craving one of their grilled cheeses right now! All sandwiches come with yummy perfectly dressed salad too

Aus32SljWq-cUghdmWYWMQ.review_text: Cafe Revolution to me crowded live music - good tunes/sometimes bad.but people always listen weed smokey is okey drinking on sidewalk bad... i tend to do it anyways just to get yelled at which is a awesome cause its a revolution! is what u tell him

QLxEPPZ1JqOHJpREFkRd2w.review_text: OK, so I admit that I was a bit of an ass for taking my change back even though I had to wait 5 mins to place an order with hardly anyone there and the change was placed right in front of the bartender. So I decided I would leave a tip after I ate.  Not so sure that this justifies receiving a rude comment and then waiting 15-20 mins for a sandwich while the bartender talked to his homeboys outside. The food was put in a box rather than on a plate so I didn't notice missing ingredients and one bite for the salad right away. My stomach hurts. Left a tip when leaving in spite. I've received bad service there before as well.  Sometimes good music is played but it's super loud. Or shitty musicians might be playing their guitars and singing as loud as they can. Might go back at night for the live music.   And yes, if you don't like the smell of weed and cigs, not your place.

qinBGdCRzdbj3Sc2ZnxFQg.review_text: If you can find a seat in this place, go there. At least once. You'll be happy you did. (It does get crowded but not hectic---just crowded).  Half indoor half outdoor and spewing with culture and warmth, The Revolution Cafe is an awesome addition to the Mission with frequent live music, cozy, close-quarters seating & yummy hot drinks.  I'm more of a fan of the atmosphere here than I am of their beverages (though the beverages aren't bad). It's the perfect place to visit at night.

pQ5KN30KKqaPQGtpqvGaIA.review_text: This is a really cool cafe. I heard old time jazz here on a Friday night. the place was upbeat with excitement. Nice crowd- very ,easy to have fun with a  friend or a crowd.

uMIppVwGLc8oYKkvtqndGQ.review_text: What better than to hang outdoors with the Mission literati?  Think heat lamps, Belgian beers and ashtrays, that's what.  When you're craving a bohemian atmosphere _and_ a cigarette, viva la revolucion!

F4li3HnfS4gY5IeMSPkGcg.review_text: I went to Revolution by accident on a Tuesday night when it was warm and was pleasantly surprised by the scene, the people and the drinks.  The place felt very SF to me.  As a recent transplant from NYC, I was surprised by the eclectic energy that felt so normal for the place.  There was a band play bluesy jazz on a piano that needed tuning, folks smoking budda on the stoop, and cool people everywhere.  This is clearly one of those spots that isn't a gay/straight/divey/upscale scene, but really a collage of all those things.  I would definitely recommend this to a friend and will be back.

4XpJ4HKD5OQ3H5Gy330CkA.review_text: We need more places like The Revolution Cafe!  And perhaps spread out into different districts as well.  I love the laid back, chill atmosphere at this bar.  Everyone squishing around tables and booths, some just grabbing a chair and sitting on the sidewalk with no care in the world than to enjoy their beer on a nice evening.  I wanted something to snack on as I was drinking my beers, and they were out of the pita and hummus.  The bartender said that the guacamole was just alright and that it was okay that I buy food from next door.  Is exactly what I did.  (Carnitas nachos were only okay...they used nacho cheese..not very authentic, but I like nacho cheese.)  I would definitely go back to Revolution Cafe.  Cheap beers, chill atmosphere, nice staff and even if you're not a unkempt Mission resident, you don't feel vastly out of place.  Again, we need more types of these bars throughout the city...
