J28-pk9OsV-7kF9vxPLwQw.review_text: The Revolution Cafe is an authentic taste of the Third World:  apathetic staff, inconsistent supplies, slowly turning ceiling fans, frightening bathrooms, the works.  Despite these shortcomings, I have to rate Revolution highly because it has Chimay on tap, great sandwiches (don't even ask for substitutions or removals, though), a relaxed daytime ambience, and live music, making it a very pleasant place to while away a summer Mission day.  If you want your order quickly or prepared differently, or if you're counting on them having what you want, however, you may be out of luck.

Zn7lIByuJmQQMVTK7rNAyQ.review_text: I've been here several times, once there was a live jazz band playing. I usually like to sit outside where it's heated and you can observe people walking by. Sometimes a guy with a guitar drops by asking you if you want to have him play a song (and sing) for you. Beer for drinkers, and coffee/ tea and WiFi for those that don't. Sometimes, when it's nearly empty, I just like to sit back and watch the world pass by.

rMUKS4bLfoBXgOPRKZHzDg.review_text: Revolution has big beautiful windows but doesn't let in much light. The location might be perfect for live music but not ideal to do work during the day. The music inside was too loud. The iced coffee was meh. The barista was really sweet. I really wanted to like it but maybe I just came at the wrong time of the day.

E7o9NTPIDT8EVhz1dRwqlg.review_text: I really enjoy Revolution Cafe right from the immediate vibe to the decor and feel of the place. The staff and clientele are also super chill and friendly. Many a time at Revolution I have enjoyed a coffee, beer, or snack while listening to good music and watching the city of SF pass me by...all the while thinking, "This place is great for being a part of making all this happen."

Dp9vtkpgNti0BuG3202PGQ.review_text: Lovely place to chill on a sunny Sunday with a novel and cup of coffee.  At night, it has a more bar-ish atmosphere (they have live jazz and serve wine, beer, and sake drinks).  Revolution has unfailingly cool local art, Mission folks with revolutionary proclivities (last time I was there, a Globalize SF meeting was being held), and good music.  The live music in the evenings seals the deal.  Revolution Cafe also has pretty good panini and snacks and is right near Make-Out Room and Latin American Club.  True, the coffee is not as good as Ritual's, but you can sit outside, enjoy the sun, and NOT wait in line for 45 minutes here.  One time I was here, the DJ tried to stab someone who complained about the music he was playing.  The cops came afterwards and he bolted, ran down the street to hide in an alley, and left his DJ equipment.  There's no point to this story, except that it was weird.  And maybe a testament to Revolution Cafe bc it didn't stop me from coming back.

Z4Fkz0ET2vqvjr-Cijo9Tg.review_text: I go here once a week to get coffee before my Thursday night class on the CCSF Mission campus. I must say, I have gotten about the same results every time.  1. The staff is almost always beyond rude. I stand there and watch as the guys behind the counter just sit there and talk to their friends, will glance over and stare at me, and then go back to talking to their friends. I'm so sorry that I've meddled with your much important conversation about who puked at last night's party after doing JaggerBombs. Though, when the girls are working behind the counter, they're usually super sweet and nice. 2. When you run out of brown sugar or half-and-half, and I ask for more, I usually get the most disgusted look in the world. I'm sorry, did you think I said, "Would you mind killing your entire family and serving their heads on pikes for me please?" because that's the disgusting look you usually give me. Last time I was there, the guy made this big "to-do" about getting more sugar for me. And kept sighing and huffing, as if he was growing and harvesting the sugar for me. Get over it ya stupid emo. 3. The line for the bathroom is right near the milk and sugar, so it gets stupid crowded here, which means there's lots of crowded-ness and people complaining. Hmm...  The only reason that there is not a one-star review, from all my bitching, is that the two girls that work here sometimes are really sweet and always nice to me (the exception to points one and two from above). And, I've learned where they keep the half-and-half in the fridge next to the bathroom, so since I was given permission once to get it, I now do it all the time.  Also, they get an extra star because they always have pretty sweet artwork in here. That makes waiting in line (which is usually about 10 minutes or more for a cup of coffee) a little bearable.

18RjALXR6bCVDGaeRSx8-w.review_text: Outdoor seating is great and I like that there's free music many nights. Low key place, they sometimes have some surprises (like HeBrew and Chimay) on tap. Never tried the food. I tried to get coffee here once, but the espresso machine was on the fritz, so I can't comment on that. Never tried the food. Great 10-midnight happy hour (not sure if it is still on, last time I went was several months ago), can't beat that.

yMygl5-DYugYcGbqitXw2w.review_text: I live 45 miles from San Francisco, but the several times a month that I go to hang out in the city, more often than not I find myself spending an hour or two sitting and sipping a beverage at Revolution Cafe. There is always live music, or a dj spinning house music. The staff is friendly and pleasant. You can sit on the porch and drink with a smoke. There is consistently beautiful art on the walls. I take all of my out of town friends to the Revolution Cafe as part of my SF tour. The people who come and go are always beautiful. I cannot think of a better spot to sit and relax and watch the city walk by.

VgtcRwMPiAEeuPsayXB4kA.review_text: Another place that's taken me more than the year I've lived here to visit. Why? Because every time I try to hang here, it's overflowing with patrons.  We actually got a good table on the opposite side of where the piano is. Is that weed I smell floating inside? Um... where was I? Oh! So I got a spicy chicken sandwich and a Chimay. I love how the "fill to here" line on the special Chimay glass is totally ignored and is filled to the rim. I followed that with a Leffe. Great music tonight, too.  Verdict: Approved.

xUoK9KmxHK7wKOXdDSruMw.review_text: Beautiful for a Sunday night! Great music played by talented local artists.   The place is teeny, it's packed, and there's barely any place to sit or move (the bow of the violinist was almost in my face!) but it's a cozy amicable environment. The sandwiches are also very tasty and the bartender friendly (if a little bit rushed as a one-man show in a packed house).   A little gem that's worth swinging by!

EMRSUY3hkSje0zUx5Z9Urg.review_text: After some power shopping at the Skechers outlet down the street, we stopped here for some afternoon drinks on the patio. Got to love a place that looks like a well worn French cafe playing Brazilian music  with lots of people just hanging out on a sunny afternoon. Cool atmosphere especially the cute construction guys with hard hats busy on their laptops and an another guy playing his guitar along with the music. Good wine.

j4qY94EEsq49tN4s_QY0fQ.review_text: The grilled cheese sandwiches here come with four kinds of cheesy goodness.  They even use either goat cheese or bleu cheese (I dont remember which), which adds an unexpected tang to the childhood classic.  They use the panini press to melt your sandwich into oblivion and while it makes for a nice toast, it does take about 10 minutes to go from flacid to crunchy.  A bit greasy, but you can't beat it for flavor.

PpZDAemMf9Nc9hFYXSydBQ.review_text: This is a must-visit spot every time I roll to SF. The live music is a great addition, and I have sat here for hours and hours eating, drinking and chatting with friends.   My most fond memory, however, is that this is the place where I unlocked and jailbroke my iPhone. Yep, with my macbook and their wifi, nothing could stop me. It's so appropriate that I liberated my technology at "revolution" cafe.  Thanks yall.

ISTrVRtMD8UDMzMwaaLglg.review_text: What everyone is saying here is spot-on, but no one has thus far mentioned that the cocktails are all made with the soju/sake rather than what I affectionately call booze. Hey, you do what the SF fuzz will permit you to, pardon the pun, but I thought you might want to know that your $6 "mojito" (sorry, but to me the quotes are compulsory if it ain't rum) is only gonna get you half as loopy as one from a venue with a liquor license (and in my opinion, the flavor is a mile away). Word to the wise!

7efUCemTBpNuwTRDkC5JvQ.review_text: Hard not to like this place. It's a great spot to sit on the sidewalk on a sunny day; if it isn't sunny (or if the outside places are just full), the inside is comfortable & welcoming. Live music is a nice touch, too.

J9b9YUP1bWSkO3T7XS6uYA.review_text: This place is great - it is open until 2AM and perfect when  you feel like going out, but don't want to drink.  The atmosphere is perfect - it is an open air restaurant at night and I just love sitting outside and sipping my drink.

e77JyltArqckcdBl13bVbA.review_text: This place really keeps getting better.  The coffee is exceptional, the beer selection impressive, and they served me a delicious tomato soup last time I was in.  Gonna hafta upgrade them to 5 stars.

v-kh_W7iWpKOIux2Gx2q1g.review_text: No thanks to the name of this cafe/bar, the whole night I had ... "ready for a revolution...heeeyyy...revolution...." stuck in my head. Alas.  I like this spot --- it's an awesome place to people watch and catch up on Spanish eavesdropping skills. My friend's hot chocolate was awesome, and my sangria was blah.  On the downside, there's a lack of seating due to the free internet, and there are a few too many smokers for my taste.

qhGUtlMKxDkiNHg0xkkj3g.review_text: Cool spot to have a beer and take your laptop for the free wireless.  Not many spots where you can do that.  Don't care about the coffee and food to much, just the beer and wine options.  When the sun goes down, the spot converts into a cool bar to have conversations with buddies with the occasional band playing.
